content:
Posted: April 22, 2016
												I'm fairly new to PC Simulation gaming, the main reason I bought my rig was for Race Sims and so far my time has been spent mostly on RaceRoom Racing Experience. I can't quite put my finger on why. the game feels much, much smoother than the other two i've played (Assetto Corsa and Automobilista), i'm yet to give others a go. Along with having a superior sense of speed, I believe the cars handle much closer to their real life counterparts, mainly because i've been behind the wheel of an open wheeler and it bought back a few key memories and feelings. Annoyingly, the game is a money pit, but hey, the base game is free and i'd be more than happy to invest on just the GT series and WTCC series, but... That's not me, I need them all!!! I've had a blast in the masters and WTCC series so far. I'm really, really hoping they can pick up a WEC license at some point, then this game will literally be my go to. The tracks seem pretty solid, Brands Hatch feels really solid, incredibly close to the real version, this is the only track I know from person so the only one I can really push. Other tracks also feel solid, Force Feedback seems to be creditable with a nice road feel and tyre lean coming through the wheel nicely. RaceRoom seems to be the only game to give me a close race all the way through the race, others seem to have the ai drop off a little at stages. My one annoyance with RaceRoom is that I seem to blast the Qualifying 1 or 2 seconds faster than second place but then the ai stick with me through the race, even though my lap times barely drop off from qualifying. Not that i'm complaining, I love bumper to bumper action that the WTCC delivers. But from my amature opinion, I'd chose RaceRoom over Assetto Corsa and Automobilista, but only for now, Assetto Corsa seems to be going places fast, especially now there's a console version to push the developers a bit. Automobilista is a fantastic sim too, so ♥♥♥♥ing fun, i've never even heard of the developers but they've done a banging job! As soon as they get their hands on a new graphics engine, things are going to go pretty sweetly for them. I believe they got there's engine from the first version of a very popular racing sim with an insane tyre model. They're sticking with it because they know the engine so well which is fair enough, it does need updating though XD But yeah... Add WEC with multi category racing and i'll fall in love with RaceRoom.

content:
Posted: April 25, 2016
												Don't be fooled by people telling you the content was overpriced. There's lots of it and you can get most or all of it if you get it on sale directly through the in-game store or website for little more than a full-priced game would cost. I payed about 70€ throughout a year and own all but 4 tracks and have access to about every racing class there is (and there's so many). And I could have gotten the same content even cheaper if I waited for some special opportunities.Just stay away from the packages offered on Steam, they are usually way overpriced. An exception is the new Nürburgring Legends pack. The content, if you don't own anything of it yet, would cost you almost 35 € in the store if you count the single prices for the cars and tracks (which you would normally buy within other packs like GT3, WTCC2015 et cetera where they are also cheaper). Here you can grab it for 15€. With this pack you get two tracks with 7 or 8 layouts, including the Nordschleife, and the cars give you access to about 7 classes I think in which you can participate either in Multiplayer or against AI (AI also uses the cars you don't own yourself). Combine this with the European track pack from the in-game store for example and you already have tons of contents for much less than a full price game would cost you.Apparently the new WTCC 2015 pack on Steam is also quite a good deal if you don't own any of the content yet and prefer to have access to all cars of the 2015 series. It offers a wide variety of tracks with it.If you are new to this game, check it out - you get 11 cars and 3 tracks (2 circuits and 1 hillclimb) for free.The sounds are second to none, absolutely amazing.The Forcefeedback has just gotten a complete overhaul so even if you tried the game at an earlier point already it's worth checking out again. It's great, especially since a lot of classes have also gotten or are about to get a physics update. The new content all have great physics, GT3 also has just been updated. This is of course just my personal taste, but with the new physics and ffb, the driving in this feels a lot better then in Assetto Corsa and PCars anyway.Graphics are nice, tracks have much detail but the game seems to be relatively demanding. On my old 7950 I have to set shaders to medium to get a minimum of 60fps with more than 20 cars on screen.Sadly, the game is lacking weather effects and night racing.The AI however is the best I have ever encountered in a racing game. They give you a good fight, they make mistakes and they usually have a very good player awareness. It often feels like driving against real drivers in MP. Sometimes they are buggy though. A few corners can make them problems depending on with how many cars you're racing and recently they started to take not enough fuel for longer races and some of them go for refueling 1 or two laps before a race ends. But things like this are usually ironed out quickly by the devs.The menus are a lot more cleaned up than AC, and a lot more efficiently designed than PCars.Imo, if you don't want to pay a sh*tpile of money for iracing this is the best sim out there atm with a very nice community.

number of helpful: 8 of 8 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 23, 2016
												My #2 next to Project Cars. I simply wish there was a safety car, weather and time progression and dynamic road surface (rubbering etc.). There is just something about night racing. Granted the casual player would not even bother with these features, this is for the more dedicated hard core player. Seems when it comes to racing games there is a trade off that needs to be made between fun and seriousness, in my opinion this is a pure racing simulator and it doesn't try to be anything else. All cars are race spec, there are no road cars, no parts to buy for the car, no livery editor, etc. You get real life counter parts from real series mimicked ala iRacing.The sound is fantastic, the feel of the cars is much improved over the early beta days, the visiual presentation is fantastic albeit a bit dated (DirectX 9). Overall it gives a fantastic race experience that with hopeful VR support be extremely immersive. The studio has a lot of talent and great foundation to make a next generation simulator in the future. Hopefully they realize their vision in the next iteration, I can only hope that the backend gets replaced while the game stays the same title, no need for a RRRE2, just keep it RRRE and keep improving what is already there.I highly recommend it, if you do try this out, hop in the sillhoutte series cars at the raceroom raceway track (both awesome car and track!) and be sure to use a while, you loose a lot of immersion and feel of the game using a game pad or keyboard, its not gonna give you a poor experience. A G25 works perfect here.I have bought nearly all the content for the game and I am not even upset, you can get vRP from the raceroom store, which is cheaper than buying the cars and tracks within the game, first get the vRP reedem it in the game then buy the packs it will save you a lot of money. I recommend buying the packs that have cars and tracks in them, then the track packs then car packs as you wish. It will maximize the content and getting the 10K vRP for 60$ yields you nearly 90% of the content. This is not different than buying any modern game now, just wish they made it simpler than this.

content:
Posted: June 11, 2015
												R3E is really a terrific racing sim! It was perhaps launched too early with many features lacking or functioning badly, but recently, though still in beta, it has really delivered in my opinion.I also have the "other two" contemporary racing games, AC and pC and I must say that I find R3E most fun of these three. For example, I think BMW M1 Procar is even more fun to drive in R3E than it is in pC which I find a blast in pC also. R3E is not perfect, at least yet, but it surely has its strengths. Sounds are just awesome and with the recent 9GB "patch" they got even better. FFB is also best of the three games and it deliveres the road feel really well and doesn't even require hours of tinkering with settings to get it right. AI is also the most competent of the three by a big margin, so R3E is perhaps the best choice for the single players at least until AC and pC improve their AI algorithms. Graphics are also quite good, although not on par with pCars, but on the other hand, R3E runs also very well on my three monitor setup.But hey, physics are the most important thing, no? Here R3E fares also well. Physics aren't perhaps the most accurate on the planet, but still very believable and with awesome FFB I like the driving feel a lot. I say it again, I think R3E delivers the most fun experience of the three. Still, R3E is by no means arcade racer and leans heavily towards simming side of the genre.As said and at the time of writing, R3E is still in beta and a work in progress. It is still quite polished and offers pretty much full experience already. It has no weather or full night, but it is otherwise pretty much a full deal IMO. Things I dislike the most are annoying load times, which surely improved with the latest patch, but are still on the annoying side especially on the menus. Micropayment system is completely a matter of opionion and it really doesn't bother me. You can have just one experience set and that gives you several tracks and a class of cars and that's basically all you need. If you wan't more, different packs give good value for money and you get discounts for the packs of the items you already may own.If you like sim-like racing games don't hesitate to try the R3E.  You can do it for free, but of course with very limited options for driving.

content:
Posted: June 3, 2015
												8/10 Great race sim plagued by a terrible payment and content structure. I'm giving this a thumbs up only because it's actually a great racing sim experience with excellent single player AI and vehicle physics. Unfortunately you need to always be online to play. Multiplayer is still hit or miss and sometimes you will get randomly disconnected. I sincerely hope SInBin/Sector3 change this game to a flat pricing fee if they truely want to entice more players to the game. The game content is always on sale at least 50% on their website (cheaper than steam prices) so I wouldn't worry about missing out on sales. I've never seen any of the packs at full price. For example the regular price for the DTM 2014 pack is 8318 vRP or about $85 US without a discount on their site! Who would pay that much!? The permanent discount price is there to get you to buy stuff and is a classic marketing trick!If you're looking to get into Raceroom Experience with minimal cost I recommend the DTM 2013 pack and the American track pack. It only costs about $20 USD and gets you a great race series along with 13 tracks...Circuit Park ZandvoortRed Bull Ring SpielbergEuroSpeedway LausitzMoscow RacewayHockenheimringNürburgringNorisringMotorsport Arena OscherslebenBrands HatchMazda Laguna SecaMid OhioIndianapolisSonoma RacewayAfter that things ramp up in price very quickly! It'll cost you $102 USD for all tracks, three different race series and a big variety of vehicles (but not all of them). Detailed below. Keep in mind this still isn't all of the content available, probably around 75% of it!WTCC 2013DTM Experience 2013ADAC GT Masters Experience 2014DTM 1992GTR2 PackGroup 5 PackAmerican Track PackTrack: Circuit ZolderTrack: Bathurst CircuitTrack: Salzburgring* All remaining tracks included in above packs$102.59 USD Order Total (after discounts)If you want every vehicle in the game expect to pay well over $150 USD for all content. My advice is to just buy the $20 package I listed above and be happy with that. It's the 'best deal/bang for the buck' and still gets you a lot of racing action and tracks for that price.

number of helpful: 10 of 12 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 18, 2016
 My specs: Medion Notebook with GTX 670MX and i7 3630QM (Win7 Pro) + 28" Monitor (playing in fullHD)Logitech G920 + shifter Why I recommend the game: For anyone, who is into simracing, with r3e you probably get one of the best, if not THE best racing simulator on the market. I can compare to Assetto Corsa, rFactor 2 (Demo), Stock Car Extreme, Project Cars, Grid Autosport, NFS Shift and NFS Shift 2.Different to f.ex. Assetto Corsa, in r3e you can only drive real racing cars, no stock versions of them. There are not only features like tyre rubbing or fuel consumption, enthusiasts have many options to mechanically set up the car the way they want.Physics and force feedback feel great on the G920. It doesn't take long to get a feeling for the car you drive. Never the less it can be preety hard to get controll back after oversteering with some cars. Also you can set up the ffb settings by yourself, if the default ones doesen't suit you.In singleplayer the AI difficulty can be set up in small steps, just like in Asseto Corsa. There also is an adaptive mode.As far as my experiences go with multiplayer, I have a pretty good impression of the community. Didn't met a "NFS crash kiddy" yet (EDIT: you actually meet some, especially in races with free content). There are not only extremely quick hardcore racers on the way, r3e is also played by some real life racers, even from DTM.Graphics are state of the art and performance is very good. Only things I miss, are "bad" weather effects like rain and wet tracks for more slippery action sometimes. Things you should know/some people may not like: R3e may be called "freetoplay". I would describe it more like a bigger demo version of a game, which allows to configure its content the way the customer wants it. So f.ex. if you don't want to drive formula cars, you don't need to buy them. There is the option to do as many test drives as you like of every car, which is very fair in my opinion. You also can drive in hotlap competitions with cars and tracks you don't own.You can purchase every car or track seperately or buy packs (what can be cheaper). I recommend to buy VRP on the r3e store website. As far as I know, this should be the cheapest way to buy content.One thing that is pretty annoying, is the fact, that if you bought a car in the f.ex. GT Masters 2014 Version, you still need to buy the same car again (at least cheaper) in the GT3 or GT Masters 2015 Version.To sum it up: if you really want to play the game with as much content as similiar games offer, r3e is a bit expensive but the price is still OK if you buy packs or take offerings on sale. Conclusion: If you are looking for a racing simulation game and you have a ffb wheel, at least test the game in freetoplay-mode.If you are an "arcade racer" and don't want to put much effort into playing and paying, this probably isn't the game for you. Never the less you still have the option to give it a try for free :)

number of helpful: 10 of 12 people (83%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 27, 2016
												Raceroom Racing Experience was my first racing sim. I noticed R3E when steam presented me an ad for the DTM 1992 pack, featuring the Mercedes 190E. Since my first car was a Mercedes 190E and I've been watching the DTM since 1992 I had to get the game and DTM 1992 pack.My first steps in the game were kinda rough. I only had an xbox controller and other than that no clue about racing.I went to the Sector3 forums and got immediate help. Not just the usual Buy a wheel kind of advice. Also advice on how to play with a controller.Ever since my first experiences with R3E I got Assetto Corsa, Project Cars, iRacing and a wheel.People generally seem to complain about the payment system. I don't really understand what the problem is. For Assetto Corsa or Project Cars you have to pay about $50 on steam when it's not on sale and then you still have to buy DLC if you want to. R3E is free to play unlike the other sims. Ok, the free version only comes with a handful of cars and no real life tracks, but you can buy every single track and car individually or in packs. In iRacing you also have to buy cars and tracks individually but on top of that you have to subscribe to use their service. R3E's multiplayer mode has been suffering in the past, however, it's constantly being improved. My personal experience wasn't very good in the beginning. I had high ping and was constantly ghosting. That issue has been fixed and in the last few online races I haven't had any issues at all. Raceroom or Sector3 is constantly working on new content, improving the physics, and working on fixing multiplayer issues.It might not be as shiney as Project Cars is, might not have a multiplayer base like iRacing has, but it has a sound which makes the cars sound like cars, has good physics, force feedback, official licenses for DTM, WTCC, ADAC GT Masters and a growing user and fan base.

number of helpful: 12 of 16 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 2, 2016
												My first review 3 years ago was appropriately negative.  The game was an overpriced hotlapping app given the absence of AI opponents.  Now the game is my favorite racing simulation (play it more than Assetto Corsa and Project Cars right now).  I'm so glad I gave it a second chance.Heard about the massive update in November so I reinstalled the game and ran a few races and I was hooked.  The physics model is very much improved since 2013.  Combine this with remarkably better FFB and it's basically a new game.  I took advantage of the Black Friday deal and now have all the cars and tracks.  Love running the ADAC GT, DTM, Audi Sport TT, and WTCC cars.  Tracks are nicely modeled and have excellent nuances including bumps and curbs.  I especially like how well they model the loss of grip when you crest a hill.  You can really feel the wheels lift and the car lose grip.  The AI is very good.  Just run a few races and allow the adaptive AI to adjust to your skill and you'll be impressed.  I really appreciate how imperfect the AI can be, making realistic mistakes and getting into trouble yet not careless and running you off the road.  Significantly better than the AI in Assetto Corsa or Project Cars.  AI in those games feels like robots hotlapping in a perfect line.  Especially Assetto Corsa - very boring AI.  Surprised to hear about so many technical issues in other reviews.  Game runs beautifully for me.  Graphics are gorgeous and fps are fast and smooth.  I'm running an i7-6700k &  Geforce 980 Ti so most games fly.  This game seems well optimized given the 30-40 AI cars with no stutter.  Overall this game has come a LOOOOONG way in almost 4 years.  I went from being a harsh critic to huge fan.  Says a lot about Sector3 Studio's commitment to making this game great.

content:
Posted: January 17, 2016
												I've never written a review on steam before.  I have 2 kids and I hardly have time to wipe my♥♥♥♥♥because I have to wipe theirs.  I also have a stressful full time job.  Because of that, and because my favorite games are racing games, I went on the hunt for a great racing game to use as therapy.Assetto Corsa:  I tried to like it.  I really did.  But it just wasn't for me.  It's not a complete game, the environments feel dead, it felt slow, there weren't as many tracks as there are in other games, and it just bored me.  I returned it before I took my morning dump.PCars: This game is sexy af but the the ffb is an afterthought.  I also hated that there is no championship mode available.  In all honestly, it felt like a rushed simcade game.  I did appreciate the graphics and variety of tracks, but the actual driving did not grab my attention.  I didnt feel like I was a race car driver.  The half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥one player mode, and nearly optionless career mode was very Star Wars Battlefront-esque by Electronic Sharts.  I blame this microwave, insant gratification generation of subhumans for that game and this one for letting developers ravage them in this manner, although battlefront is much worse than PCars.This game:  Holy ♥♥♥♥.  The driving in this game is ridiculous.  The driving alone is so intense because of the physics engine and amazing ffb, that within one minute I was sold.  You can feel it when you mess up, and when you're about to.  That makes its so rewarding to run a good race or to recover/prevent a fishtail (which these cars do readily).  The graphics are nice, not PCars level,  but definitely pretty.  The game also runs smoothly on my computer.  I love the presentation and the tracks feel alive, but maybe its because you have to focus so hard to place!  Last but most brilliant is the sound.  My God the sound.  The sound is the icing on the cake of the immersion this game provides.  This game is the truth, and I'll go as far as to say it's my favorite racing game ever.  Also, people talk♥♥♥♥♥♥about f2p, but this is a reasonable f2p model because they have discounts for bulk purchases and you can save money by buying what you like.  In sum, ♥♥♥♥ the other games.  This game is the real deal.  The only cons for me is you can't set the length of the race by laps, only time (♥♥♥♥ you for that Sector), and the cars do an automatic 1080 if someone bumps you or you lose traction.  It's ♥♥♥♥ing stupid the way these cars spin but I guess you cant be perfect.  But literally, a ♥♥♥♥ing spectator could fart in the stands and you'll go ♥♥♥♥ing carouseling into a hotdog stand and last place.

content:
Posted: September 12, 2014
												It's basically rFactor. So of course it has great driving physics. It feels solid real and you understand why you make a mistake. It's not like NFS where cars behave as if they had plastic wheels and were driving on plastic roads. Your car handles like it should, not like a Hot Wheels car. You put too much gas, you get punished. You brake too hard, you get punished. Just like in real. But once you master a car, it'll be easy for you to set a lap time. A clear, neat interface, great sound work, great driving physics, and very decent graphics. All for free. What's not to like? Too bad its new multiplayer is riddled with crashkids, who presumably be shot to death in real life if they did the same. Simbin also likes to stick their flag notifications in the middle of your screen, blocking the apex when in exterior cam. Other than that, go grab this already. And if you have the money, get the BMW GT2 and Audi R8 LMS, they're top notch cars.

												This is a great graphical upgrade to Simbins racing games and it still has one of the best physics models. I then bought a VRP pack and used it on the Raceroom site when they had a 90% sale (they have these great sales a few times a year from what I've seen). Because I owned two of the larger packs already, I also got additional discounts. I managed to get all the packs on the site (except a couple of the single car packs), around 75% of the cars and all the tracks except 5 for around 85 dollars Canadian total. Keep in mind that Raceroom uses US dollars and my dollar was only worth about 72 cents and you see how cheap Raceroom can be if you live in the US. content:
Posted: January 7, 2015
This is a sim racing title. Which means you need a wheel to play this game, preferably a Driving Force GT or better. A gamepad will simply not do. If you are looking for something along the lines of DiRT or Need for Speed, this game is definitely not for you.Now that's out of the way, R3E, in it's current state, is a solid contender in the sim racing genre. Physics feel great and the force feedback is pretty much what you would expect from a racing sim. The game has fantastic sounds and AI that pretty much blows every other modern sims out there out of the water. However, the game does have major flaws which I will talk about further down.ProsFANTASTIC AIIt's pretty much the best out there. Heck, I would even go as far to say that it rivals the old Papyrus sims in terms of AI intellegence and speed. They will not  brake early in the first corner for you to pass every single one of them before the first lap. They will not drive into you because they follow a specific line around the track. You can actually see them race each other and take different lines as you catch them while they slow each other down. They will try to take their position back if you manage to overtake them. You pass someone coming out of a turn and the next thing you'll now, they're back at your side for the upcoming turn. They also sometimes cause accidents of their own which spices things up a little. Overall, it's a nice alternative to public lobby online racing.GOOD SOUNDSProbably the best sounding sim we have, next to the V8 Brazilian Stock Cars of Game Stock Car Extreme IMO. The DTM 1992 pack is probably my favorite. You could hear the car suffering when you damage the transmission, and you could also feel that you are slowing down because of it, which you are.Good car and track selectionThere's a decent amount of tracks and cars in this game. No road cars though. Not that it matters much.Nice GraphicsNot much of a graphics guy, but they do look good. Not as good as Assetto Corsa though.A great sim for single racesIt's a no brainer. The AI can provide very challenging races even if you don't crank the difficulty up. Since every track is made by Sector 3, you can expect the AI to be consistently good on all the track and car combo you can throw at it.ConsThe Free2Play SystemThis one is pretty obvious. Yes, you can only choose to buy one pack if you wanted to. But sooner or later, you will want the DTM pack too, which is another $27. And then you find out that Laguna Seca isn't included in the pack. That's gonna be another $5. And then you feel like you want to try the old touring cars, which costs about $10 if you want to buy all of them. I forgot Monza. Another $5 for that. You've pretty much spent twice the amount of Assetto Corsa and get half of its content through modding.NO CUSTOM SKIN SUPPORTSeriously? Every sim racing game out there ENCOURAGES you to paint your own skins by giving out templates for the cars. This one only comes with the stock skins each car has.ALWAYS ONLINEFor a sim that's best for singleplayer, it's kinda ironic that it has to be always online. Not to mention that multiplayer is pretty much dead.UNMODDALEEver wanted to try an F1 car with the gane's fantastic AI? NOPE! Gotta wait for Sector 3 to do it. That is, if they even consider having F1 in this game.Flag rules not fully implementedThis may be nitpicking a little. You can get black flagged, but yellow flags are nonexistent I believe.Despite the glaring issues of the game, the AI alone makes the game worth getting. If you don't feel like going to iRacing for an online race, you can have R3E for a great single player experience. Doesn't matter if you're driving GT3 or DTM at Sachsenring or Nurburgring. You can expect to have a really good time with the AI.

content:
Posted: September 10, 2016
Pros:- SOUND!!! Best in a racing game ever- the feeling of driving a car... unbelievable. Tons of fun. You have to feel it for yourself. I wish EVERY racing game had so realistic and pleasant physics and driving model as this game!- supports keyboard, mouse, gamepad, wheel... very satisfying gameplay on any of those.- Force Feedback. I mostly hate force-feedback in games and always turn it off (at least on a gamepad), because it's bloody annoying. Here... here it's a pure masterpiece.- camera controls- replays, saving replays, playing replays (really not common thing these days)- you can test any car and track for free unlimited amount of times- well - it's free (but for a price)- highly configurable in every aspect- runs blazingly fast even on low-end hardware- real-world drivers play it for fun too (they are uniquely indicated)Cons:- no story mode/campaign/objectives/modes etc. - something which would certainly make it more interesting- quite expensive tracks and cars when all summed up- graphics are a weird mix of modern and old standards- why I can get way better time than the Zonda R Nordschleife world record?

content:
Posted: June 1, 2016
												For racing enthusiasts or performance car fans this is a definite add to the "garage". The sound effects are first class as mentioned in many reviews. Definitely music to the ears and makes the adrenaline pump, simply outstanding. Having completed my racing license and tracking several sports/race cars over the years, I find the physics very good. Professional high calibre racers would be better suited to comment on the precision of the various cars. It would be great to have a career mode introduced to add to the immersion, this would bring me back to the track more often.The negative reviews with thumbs down due to pay to play model are both unfair and unrealistic. RacRroom make it possible to drive a couple cars and tracks free to sample the game, same as a demo of many other games/sims. Then if you like it, help keep the franchise going by purchasing some cars, tracks or both. If you don't enjoy it, nothing invested. For five or six bucks you can have a couple cars and learn to drive them properly. To truly learn a car and track takes a fair amout of seat time, so there is no need to drop a whole bunch of money right off the bat anyway, then, add as you go.Having only sampled the online competions they seemed ok. This is not what I'm after personally so really have no valid input regarding online human v human competition.In summary, this an excellent and fun sim; for a performance car or racing enthusiast you can't go wrong with RaceRoom.

content:
Posted: January 31, 2015
												The game is good fun once you get into it. Nearly everyone I've talked to who has truely taken the time to learn the physics, you'll need to adjust your wheel to you, which will take time. After which it's very enjoyable. I've had so much run racing the 1992 DTM cars, and the 2014 DTM Experience is a great singleplayer experience. the full length championships are my personal favorite. However you cannot properly handle the cars on a Keyboard. A gamepad is an improvement, the Microsoft Speed Wheel is probably the best you can do without getting a proper wheel and pedal setup. I have tired all of these avanues prior to getting a Fanatec GT3RS wheel and CSR pedals.  If you want to get into it, look into getting either Logitech G25 or G27, Fanatac Wheel (Porsche, CSR or clubsport), or a Thrustmaster T500RS, or T300RS.  IT may seem like a big jump, but if you want to really apprechiate Sim Racing, it's the only way to go.There are only a few drawbacks I've found with R3E. First, the interface takes a bit to get use to, it's not as intuitive as it could be. Second, The time investment to dial in your controller settings, Lastly the online hoppers are pretty dead overall (although it's still in Alpha, so here's hoping it'll get better in time).

number of helpful: 8 of 10 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 4, 2015
												Edit after a year or so. This sim just keeps getting better. The latest release with the fantastic nordschleife really puts this at the top of the racing hill. They also worked out a few bugs that were sometimes interrupting the fun - no more. What was previously a great game with issues is now starting to really get polished. There is no better sim racing experience that getting into a good online race with this game. Shell out the $20 for some paid content, join some big-boy races with respectful racers, and never look back. The pricing model works well for me because i can buy once (still cheaper than the other sim) and not worry about a subscription. Again, no other racing sim gets my adrenalin flowing like this one - it really conveys the feel of speed and competition. Single player is quite good as well especially for European racing fans, but i'm more of a multiplayer user. Again if you are a sim racer and have not tried this in the last year, do yourself a favor and try it again - then judge for yourself. Even using the free content to get a taste should convince most. There is still the odd bug or two, but the devs pay attention and always take care of the issues that the community brings up - for instance - currently player names above the cars are located off screen for triple monitor users. I believe this is about to be fixed in the next patch (as of 6/13/16), along with taking care of those with low ping to not ruin races. Check out the forums here https://forum.sector3studios.com/index.phpFinal thoughts - at 450 hours played, i really should be faster! But i'm getting there....Original Review: Great racing sim. There are sims that do certain things better (AC graphics for instance) but as a whole package, this is the sim that makes me feel the most like i'm in a car driving and gets my heart pounding. You just feel like you are there, which is the whole point of a sim right? The Raceroom track that comes free is great too, and i like being able to pay for what i want, even if it can get pricey if you want a ton of content. Thumbs up!

number of helpful: 8 of 10 people (80%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 26
												It's not the perfect SIM, and never will be. Imo, for the perfect SIM you need them all. I own, AMS, PCars, Dirt Rally, Race 07 and although I enjoy playing them all I have over 400hrs in Raceroom compared to 40+ in other Sims. Graphics rant up to PCars standard, nice and it is dx9, but physics and Emerson are way above. I love this game and my system with only a 750ti can max out most graphics , so those with bigger cards have 4k,VR and silly amounts of A.I at thier disposal. The free to play base game comes with enough tracks and cats to hook you into making some dlc purchases and factoring in costs of buying a game and/or content/season pass, Purchasing starter pack or even the pro pack gives good value.There are some bugs and some key elements missing, but there is a very good community and a good dev support via the Raceroom forum.Single player is great fun with the improving A.I, and some close races can be both fun and rewarding. Car physics and force feedback, especially the dtm/gt3, is some of the best I have experienced, AMS may just nudge ahead but but then loses out on the visual and immersion. Sounds too are amazing and really pull you in with surround sound and cockpit view.I've only played a few multiplayer races and can't really say much about that, usual w reckers on free content servers,not all, but there are some good community leagues and the game itself a host competitions, some of which have prizes to be won.I would recommend this game to anyone who enjoys track driving and although best enjoyed with a wheel, imo, there is full support for control pad.

number of helpful: 6 of 7 people (86%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 1, 2015
												This is a great game,  Yes for FREE you only get a few cars and tracks, but its not P2W. If you don't have the cars/track then you cant race, so your never at an disavantage. There is 50+ cars to get, but a pack are better value as you can get tracks and cars. PROS:Other than race using you own purchased tracks and cars, RaceRoom has these two great features;* Practice in any car.  Seen a car you like, give it spin for free.  Same track each time, so you can get a really good feel for the car.* Race Room Competitions.   These are free and you don't need to have purchased the tracks and cars. You compete time trails against other players and your ghost car and you are ranked in a league.  CONS:  * Mainly a single player experience at the moment . Muliplayer is good but still in alpha.* DO NOT BUY ANY DLC FROM STEAM. Instead buy content from the game portal, which is connected to your steam account.They have sales and at the moment you can get DTM 13 for £6.20.  It will also give you a small volume discount and if you buy a pack which has tracks and cars that you already own, then you get a futher discount.  For example I have DTM 13, so DTM 14 is £9.20.  I'm making the jump from from arcade to sim racing and this is much more user friendly and cheper than iracing and even Assetto Corsa. Play it yourself and see what you are missing.

 but limited to a couple of tracks and car modelsOther stuff you can buy in the storei bought the euro and yank tracks and GT2 and GT3 series cars for around 20usd in game storeSteam also sells pack number of helpful: 8 of 11 people (73%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 22, 2015
												I have to say firstly i don't write reviews, but i felt i had to as this game is massively under rated.  So much has changed i'm glad i gave it another go. I thought it had lost its way a while back but things have certainly changed for the better. Definitely one of the best sims out there atm, Graphics are good, 3 screens looks good, a little optimization would help so fps are more stable, that said its not an issue, i am running it on ultra where possible and it only drops to 58 occasionally with vsync on. The 980's are coping nicely.Sounds are very realistic and clear, surround is good.The AI are the best in any racing sim right now.The cars feel good, the feedback to the Fanatec Clubsport is excellent, FWD WTCC cars are spot on, that said the BMW is awesome, driven correctly it will stay with and often beat the FWD cars which can be tough on certain circuits.Had a lot of online races and thoroughly enjoyed every one of them, just need to be able to host servers ourselves but the multiplayer clearly states alpha so i'm happy to be able to even race online right now.There are a nice selection of tracks, would like to see some more from the UK but that's my preference.I purchased the majority of my content while on sale, not sure i could justify the full price to be honest as it seems too expensive as it marketed as a "FTP" game, which kind of leaves you feeling mislead and maybe a little cheated. My suggestion, try it, get some content on next sale, you will be pleasantly surprised. The free stuff didn't appeal to me at all, the paid content obviously is a lot better (for me).Never know the dev's may realise all they need to do is sell it as a normal game none of this "FTP" marketing, then people should buy it.  Simples

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 16, 2015
												This game really does need a steering wheel / pedal set to get the best out of it. Controlling any of the cars with the keyboard is hard. A game controller might make things a bit easier, and the game does support mouse steering, but neither of these is ideal. The free to play content has some very high powered cars which make keyboard control even more difficult, which is one reason that a lot of players give up after a short time.If you've got a wheel and pedals it's a different matter. I love it. The cars feel 'alive' - challenging and fun to drive. The AI is really solid, the sound is awesome and the graphics are nice too. A real gem - the ADAC GT Masters 2014 and DTM 2014 packs are simply brilliant and make for some seriously exciting racing against the AI. It's good online tooUpdated stuff....Some folk are complaining about the "free 2 play" description for RaceRoom. I agree, it's a bit odd, maybe the label's a hangover to the old SimBin days. The free content isn't a particularly good example of what the game's actually like. There's a (non-Steam) demo of the ADAC GT Masters 2014 pack available here: http://adac-gtm-experience.com/demo/there's also a DTM 2014 demo here:http://www.dtm-experience.com/en/demo/might better show the game off.The price of the content varies a lot depending on how and when you buy it. If you take a little time figuring out what's included in each pack, it's possible to get a pile of good tracks and a car set for £12 - £15 - the DTM 2013 experience is particularly good value at the moment, even thought there's no sale on (sales come round every month or two). Once you have plenty of tracks, you can buy a single car from a car set (they're free to test) and can then use that car to race against all the other cars in that set (on or off line).If you assume that you'll spend as much as a normal full price game (say £30) then you can get a substantial slice of the content.The pace of development is impressive - lots of good stuff has been added recently like the WTCC 2014 car pack. And there's a big physics model overhaul in the works, along with a new ADAC GTM pack for 2015.One final thing, if you like the game there are some cool 3rd party addons like telemetry widgets and my own Crew Chief app here: https://forum.sector3studios.com/index.php?threads/offical-release-of-crew-chief-version-2-now-with-volume-controls-and-even-launches-r3e-for-you.2516/

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 29, 2015
												Don't let people turn you away from this game if you really like to race. It is a very good simulation but there are some that would say otherwise due to not taking the time to get to know the physics model and the fact that the gas pedal has more positions than just nothing to floored.Now thats not to say that this game doesn't have flaws. After all what games these days don't have a flaw here and there? The only big flaw for me is that the AI has vastly superiour grip to the player but you can get close with the right amount of tuning and the Devs are working on fixing that issue right now. Online races in this game are a real blast in Get Real mode but first I beg you to log practice time in this mode. Based on the multiplayer races I have seen lately people think that get real mode is going to be like driving a normal car in real life.Now the problem with that kind of thinking is that the engines on these cars are made to go much faster than a normal car that you would drive daily so Get Real mode takes some practice but after you master it it is definately the best mode. Another thing the devs might add soon is an offline mode which will be great for unexpected times of internet outage since you would still be able to log some track time if you want.In short yes this game has some flaws but so does every other game ever developed so if you really like racing give this a try. I mean its free so you've got nothing to lose except a little bit of time if you don't like the game but wouldn't you have burned that time gaming anyway?

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 4, 2014
												After almost two years of floaty physics, stuttering, bad communication, outrageous prices and lack of racing, R3E is finally turning around. Regular sales bring the content to more sensible prices, the force feedback has been tightened up to give better information about the car, the physics are more precise and very detailed and the setup makes a big difference. Most of the racing right now is in the DTM series, but the challenges are fun and allow you to try several cars and tracks without paying a dime. Visually, it's a bit bright and bold, but the environments look good and clear. Visibility and details are high, and the shadows passing on the dashboard look really nice. The performance on High settings with 8x AA with a 750ti is 60 fps when there's only one car, so I think the optimization is pretty good as well.The sounds are probably the best you'll hear in a racing game, whether it's the samples themselves or just the richness of the chassis squeaking, the transmission, the tires, etc. Everything is there and sounds great. No other game comes close.The interface is still complex and confusing, and some options are only available from the main menu. The FFB is very adjustable, but the settings are not explained much, so it takes a lot of fiddling to get everything right. For me, that means G25 and TH8RS. The modern cars don't default to auto-clutch, which is lame. Because the game looks and sound so good, and now that the FFB is finally letting the new and tighter physics shine through,  Raceroom is becoming a killer racing game. I never thought it could be possible, but out of this could arise a GTR3 people have hoped for. In the meantime, doing time trials, challenges and racing in DTM is a lot of fun.To newcomers: skip the free content and go straight for the competitions, this is where the higher quality content is. It cycles through cars and tracks regularly, so you can sample stuff until you find what you like. The freebies are still the old wobbly garbage from 2012, it seems. I think everything will be updated over time.

												After giving all the popular sim titles a try, I keep coming back to R3E. The vehicle physics feel just as accurate and responsive as iracing and miles better than PCars or AC. What really sets this game apart, though, is the closeness of racing. I have never played another game where you can race inches apart from other online drivers for laps on end without lag or ghosting interfering. The p2p multiplayer system is almost flawless in my experience.

content:
Posted: February 8, 2016
												So here I am writing a review for RaceRoom Racing Experience. So my first impressions of the game are good, in terms of gameplay the sounds are immaculate and very realistic. The force feedback you recieve through the wheel are really good and racing is challenging especially in multiplayer.Pros:-Great Sounds-Great Force Feedback-Car models look good-Racing is a challenge and you feel like you are in a real car-Has support for all controllers (wheels and joysticks and controllers)-You can make your own overlay for a race and broadcast it live-If you drive the wrong way you ghost meaning that trolls cannot crash you out using a head on collision-Physics and handling are very realistic-Different modes: Novice, Amateur and Realistic-Decent Graphics and fps with support for high end and low end spec computers-Good default overlay-So many things that can be changed in settingsCons:-The free mode only comes with 3 (I think) car series and 2 (I think) tracks-No pit crew/garage interior-No Career mode where you can make your own racer and have any sort of car improvement-Mirror visibility is not great and hard to depict cars until they are too close to try and defendI realise this game is still in development and i am looking forward to more content but I think sector3 studios have done a fantastic job on this game so its a thumbs up from me.Therefore I would rate it 9/10 as there could be a few things that could be improved (like adding some more free dlc etc.) but it surprised me with how good the gameplay was.

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 7
												tl:drRaceroom Racing Experience is a competent racing sim but also a good videogame that is easy to recommend to both a more hardcore audience as well as friends of racing games in general. The recommendation does come with a "but" or two, some minor, some major. At the very least see bolded part a couple lines below before deciding to spend money on it.The Cons-R3E is a free "content sold separately"-type of game, which almost inevitably means ALWAYS ONLINE DRM. Occasionally the server is under a heavy enough load for even the main menu to barely work, which is really frustrating as you might imagine.-The collision physics - at least against the AI - are complete BS. Just tapping an AI driver with your car tends to send you into an unrecoverable, Mario Kart style spin for no apparent reason. It's far from undriveable in singleplayer, but I can't understand why such an obvious issue has persisted for years.-While you can turn off all the camera shake to alleviate potential motion sickness issues, it leaves you with a camera that is completely rigid relative to the chassis. With lower cars like formulas and prototype cars it can result in really intense shaking that makes it hard to see where you're even going. I've never gotten motion sick but I had to just stop after a race with the formula 2 cars at Zolder and do something smooth because the constant shaking made me feel a bit queasy. GT cars are much more manageable.-Raceroom is not at all moddable, and the rigid nature of what you need to own to race with cars from a series can be a turnoff for some people.-The FOV setting is a multiplier, but there's no mention anywhere of how wide the default field of view is.I think that's most of them. I'll update later if I remember anything else that I'm not too happy about. On to the pros!Pros-Like I mentioned in the tl;dr section, it's a decent enough racing sim, but of all the sims I do own (iRacing, AC, Rfactor 2), this is the one where I sometimes just put the difficulty to amateur and race with all the magic stability assists and stuff, because the driving remains fun. This is also the only of the aforementioned sims with an inbuilt Championship mode.-The variety of cars and tracks is good. Now, the complete package is ridiculously expensive, but Raceroom offers roughly videogame-priced packages that gives you a series of cars and some tracks to race around on. It's also very easy to be picky after you have tracks. For example to race a series, let's say GRT3 since it's the GT3 class with the highest variety of cars, you only need to buy one of the cars and a livery from that class. That's roughly 3€ total. The AI is free to drive even the cars you don't own. The tracks are the expensive part, at around 5€ each. Still a better deal than iRacing I suppose.-The AI races you hard. It probably only loses to Rfactor 2 in the competition for the best racing AI. The abovementioned collision issues are there, and the AI likes to stick its nose wherever there's a gap for even a second, but largely they leave you just enough room to fight for position without being punted out.-R3E is the best sounding racing sim by far. All the chassis squeaking and stuff really adds to immersion.-My experience is that the game runs really well for how it looks. Not sure how it is with higher performance machines.-Force Feedback might not be the objectively best one, but it sure is extremely customizable.

content:
Posted: February 20, 2015
												-I've played a lot of racing sims in my day (read old guy) I had nascar back in the day, luved it, had Grand Prix legends (now there was a racing sim for hard core enthusiests), So when I say I enjoy playing this, then its probably pretty good.The physics and damage models are well done. shows some definate time and effort. Bear in mind though; as I haven't had an adac car doing 120MPH all i can do is say that it "feels" good. They have 3 settings for driving: novice/not so novice/ and what they call "get real" Each one has incrimental setting controls over the previous to the point where you can control the bump and rebound and spring rate of your car. I like this, it's more immersive and should give you better handling characteristics. Which I don't know about yet as I'm still in the novice stage, and you learn real fast not to have a heavy foot. See the warning sign for the corner?...means brake...now! I did try the "get real" setting though, and I found it a lot more "hands on" if you know what i mean.One thing about this game is it is a micro-economy game. If you want more tracks you need to purchase them along with cars. You can purchase them in packs or 1 at a time, The packs are cheaper to buy cars and tracks "enmasse" but more than individual purchases (I bought a daytona car for $3 USD and a track for $2USD), whereas if I purchased a pack it may run me $50 with 5 cars and several tracks. There is a definate learning curve, and if you don't like actual racing simulations then you should move on to a more "friendly" arcade racing game. As the AI in this will definately give you a run for your money. Although I found it a tad too pushy sometimes, they have no qualms about hitting you, and that sucks when you 2nd 3 laps in and then your last and 15 seconds back of the pack!! I haven"t gotten into any online races yet (kinda wanna get to the point where I'm not hitting every wall first) But There is a lot of online servers, however for where I am, there seems to be less closer ones with a lower ping. hopefully thats just a time differential.all in all I like this game. I find the graphics nice (but I'm not sight-seeing at 120MPH approaching a chicane lol), and there is a lot of variety. The sounds are nice (deep throaty engines and squealing of tires.), and the user interface is also nice. If your stuck on something and want to immerse yourself into racing, then this is a good purchase, just be patient. there is a definate learning curve. Thank god for my wheel...definately need a wheel!

content:
Posted: February 7, 2016
												I have no idea why there are so many negative reviews.  Nevertheless, the reviews were so bad about a year ago that I didn't touch it.  So I did wait until Dec 2015 to try it out after all the patches and changes that seemed to make it worth buying.  I race in iRacing, PCars, Assetto Corsa, FM, FH, and now RaceRoom.  The graphics inside the cockpit and looking out to the opponents is probably the best among these sims providing you have a decent PC and can max out the graphics.  I give it a 9.5/10 for graphics.  The physics are also very good since you can adjust many settings in the FFB.  So if you make a few adjustments, then I would easily say 9/10 on phyiscs.  And with all the adjustments you get for the feel, then nearly a perfect.    The gameplay is focused on DTM and GT3 in my opinion and that is pretty much why I bought it.  No other sims have anything really in the DTM class although I am hoping PCars gets into DTM more.  So if you like DTM, I can tell you this is the best sim for DTM.  I haven't had any issues at all and have to say the negative onslaught this game gets is just not accurate.  But there seems to be a few issues.  Like with the fuel and tire wear set to real, they don't seem to ever go down.  It's 100% all the time so I think that is a bug.  And the AI is annoying until you learn how to avoid them.  But this is one of the best sims out there in my opinion, especially DTM and GT3.  I just don't understand how people can spend 15 min on a game and slam the heck out of it.  Their connectivity issues and setup is more than likely their own setup problem.  Yes, it needs a little help with car setups too like adding tire pressure...lol  But the game feels and looks excellent,  It's worth the money for DTM for sure.Update: 4/30/2016 - RaceRoom is Awesome!  I've waited a month after the 3/31/2016 update that massively improved the GT3 and Prototype physics.  The new physics and new FFB settings, new car setup, especially for GT3, ADAC GT Masters, DTM, and the new Audi P1 along with Nordschleife puts this sim to the stellar level in my opinion.  In addition, the fuel and tire wear now works finally.  Neverthelesss, the new FFB meter to check for clipping is very nice.  I am very critical of physics and so you know where I am coming from, Assetto Corsa and iRacing have the top slot with PCars a close second.  Race Room was just behind PCars.  Unfortunately, Forza just doesn't have the physics at these levels, e.g. you cannot feel the rubber on the road and utilze braking to control the cornering accurately in Forza Motorsport at least yet.  So Forza is last in the physics ranking among all these.  But I am now putting RaceRoom up there at the Assetto Corsa and iRacing level.  I am at the point of saying the physics in Race Room, at least for the DTM, ADAC, GT3 and Prototype classes, is possibly even better than Assetto Corsa and iRacing.  The sound in Race Room is also stellar if not the best among the aformentioned sims and I am not even using 7.1 yet just stereo.  Race Room does not get the recognition it deserves....another point is I am astonished it's onlyh using DX9c where all the others I've mentioned are on DX11 or even DX12.  So it blows me away they are getting this level of crisp graphics viewing the opponents cars and interior that they do....congrats Race Room for pulling that off.

number of helpful: 6 of 8 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 25, 2016
												I don't often review games (or anything else), but with all the thumbs down this has gotten I decided it needed my input.  First let me say that I raced real cars for 9 years on both ovals and road courses. I've also sim raced on and off since about 1992.  I'm not an expert on sim racing, but I've tried most of the major players and R3E is among the very best -- I find the physics to be superb, at least when used with a good wheel and pedals.  I can't comment on how it plays on kb, controller or anything else and frankly I don't care.  One of the problems with sim racing is how to represent the loss of traction that one *feels* in the real world through balance, touch and seat of the pants. A common perception in the sim world is that a game is realistic when it is very difficult, but the real world isn't like that -- vehicles only get very difficult close to the limit.  I think R3E does an admirable job of balancing difficulty without crossing the line into "arcade".  Is it better than iRacing or Assetto Corsa? I don't know....that's really on a car-by-car basis for me, but some of them are better and none that I've driven are really bad (and even iRacing has had some stinkers).I also don't think the "free to play" system is that bad.  You can have some great fun without ever buying anything!  Certain track and car combinations are always available (for free!) in the "competitions".  These are really just hot-lap contests, but they are fun and you get to try out the content.....and it is still free.  Raceroom is expensive if you buy all the DLC, but I just don't see a need for that -- just buy whatever series you want to race in, and if you are really cheap just by one car in each class.  Either way it is still a lot cheaper than iRacing.  The downsides of Raceroom:-the severs are usually empty, but then I don't use this for online racing. - the AI can be a bit aggressive, but are otherwise pretty good.  -can't save setups (really????).  I've heard this is coming in the next update

content:
Posted: January 9, 2016
Brief ReviewR3E (RaceRoom Racing Experience) is a free-to-play racing simulator, which means you can download it for free, and drive a small selection of cars and tracks. The rest of the content is purchased using "vRP": R3E's own currency. vRP can be bought for a reasonable price, or can be won in competitions. This makes R3E somewhat of a budget friendly simPros and ConsProsAudioAudioAudioFFBSatisfying FFB kick on gear changesOveral good physicsConsCars have over exaggerate grip levelsPricey for some but not as bad as iRacingAn EndingDid i mention the Audio is spot on

content:
Posted: December 14, 2014
												...And I thought Gran Turismo was brutal (S-Class License in that game was not easy to obtain, BTW. Fortunately, not a requirement in this one. I also beat GT3 and most of GT4. So I'm familiar with the overall brutality of these simulators.). Then again, it's been ages since I last played a simulation racing game (At least 5 years worth of rust on me); and now with more accurate simulation settings as such, ugh. Made a decent personal time on Get Real (without shattering my car or breaking the engine), but I needed Novice to get a better handle of when to brake overall for next time (I can survive, at least, but I'm nowhere near leaderboard-ready yet at time of post). You botch the braking anywhere (especially blind corners and chicanes), and you can mess up your entire lap, or go off course, or 180-1080 your car, and invalidate your lap (no shortcutting like I used to in GT and NFS; also no more using other cars as guardrails on certain turns either :( ).Not stopping me from playing this more, and maybe getting an expansion pack or two to have more cars to drive with and more tracks to drive on. However, as precise I can get with a keyboard, I lack pressure sensitivity in order to draw a bead more precisely; so my skills are a tad biased (better with a gamepad for these kinds of games). +20.5 seconds (1:43.334 on a track) from 1st place (Leaderboards, that is) is not good enough for me. I gotta shave off more time... If I can clear +10 seconds from 1st, then I'll be a happier driver. +5, and I'll be impressed with myself. This game is not easy, because it's less game, and more simulator. The physics are quite familiar and rather unforgiving (like reality would be), especially in Get Real (and that mode also permits fine-tuning your car's aerodynamics, gear-shift ratios, and just about everything else under the hood; and tire wear is also quite unforgiving too, so keep those in check along with your fuel). If you seek a casual racing experience, I suggest a different game, lest you want to lose some keyboards or controllers in frustration. It can become casual, however, if you're a pro at this kind of stuff.Been awhile since I've had such a detailed racing experience, so thumbs up on bringing back my memories of Gran Turismo (In due time, I'll see you guys on the Nürburgring Course (up to 10 minutes per-lap, and that's with skill and a good car; BIIIG Course (28.265 km long). An ultimate test for drivers, both skill and endurance. Look it up. In GT4, my best time was about 9 minutes, or slightly less than that, and even so, I had difficulties there.)). However, only other (personal) setback is that your real name is visible (security and such, I guess). Just a friendly heads-up for anyone else that feels like crashing into walls and cars non-stop (eg- signing up to play). The heads-up is also for those that would end up broadcasting, and still want to remain anonymous; I suggest going somewhere else for privacy while broadcasting publicly.I can imagine how this will play with Oculus support. Speaking of which, the graphics are 10/10; runs smoothly with high settings, even for older machines like mine, and the graphics are a beauty overall; the sound is also rather pretty too, for you gearheads. If you want an immersive driving experience, or want to relive an A-Spec GT experience, I recommend this. Plus, it's free to play. Despite the 10GB download (mostly locked content), what's not to love? I suggest building some experience and skill before investing in any new cars/tracks/DLC packs. At least, know you can handle it first, before burning your money on this, and then giving it a negative review from poor judgement user-side.See you on the leaderboards, and by chance, on the tracks.

												Downloaded this game because the videos and screenshots looked amazing, but it is far from being finished.  The graphics are really nice, the gameplay is simple but and it is a big but.  The menu system they've tried to do is a little complicated..Also being a free member ONLY, you get only... 4 cars max and only 3 tracks man.In order to get the other cars, which you can see from the video above you must pay real money for, there is no mutlplayer to date, it is greyed out for now.  So they should be releasing it.No multyplayer yet leaves singleplayer only, during there... You are the only racer, you get a ghost car but only 1, no other cars.  Boring!The cars you get I think is 4 max but I only noticed 2, the super car you get and a BMW..Now the handling... It does not matter what mode you select from the 2, amatuer or sim they both drive exactly the same, I tried them both out and both of them handled the exact same no difference to it, you can edit the car setup which is alright but the cars STILL feel the same.I tried to get along with this game, but the massive downfall of you having to buy the other cars and extremely limiting gameplay is a massive no no.I maybe redownload this game in the future for a little mess around with friends, WHEN they release the multiplayer but for now, it is just not ready.

												(01/2017) Very solid and complete game if you buy the tracks and cars which you like. Now updated with VR support.Good graphics, great physics, great force feedback, a lot of cars, real driver names and liveries, best sound of all racing games.Exiting single player experience with lot of customization and rule sets for e.g. DTM 2015. Sure it's not complete as there are atm no predefined sets for championships. So you have to set up the tracks, car class and rule set manually each time you start with a new championship but this also gives you total freedom setting up a championship with tracks and rules as you like.Regularly updates (content and game) and good support in the forums are definitely making this game a must buy.

content:
Posted: July 1, 2015
												A while ago I saw this game was free and got it, but decided I couldn't figure it out so I deleted it. Recently I've been looking for a decent sim for a good price. You can't get much better than free! I don't have much time on this game, but I feel as though I have enough time to write this review. So here we go.Pros:-BEST PRICE EVER-pretty graphics that run smooth on my weak pc-great physics and AI-large selection of cars and tracks to choose from for a fair price-supports all of my contollers-incredible sound-easy to use UI-the ability to test drive cars BEFORE you buy them-multiplayer (in alpha)Now the cons:-after you buy a car, you have to pay MOAR for more skins-game isn't fully developed, as there are small bugs here and there. not too bad-you have to buy stuff with "VRP", which you pay for with real money. It just confuses me.Overall, this is the most fun you can have for free if you're a gamer, and if you're a simmer, this is a great and upcoming sim with high quality DLC for a fair price. I HIGHLY recommend this game to anyone. Hey- it's free!

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 23, 2014
												YOU SHOULDN'T VIEW THIS AS A FREE TO PLAY GAME.Yes it's listed as free-to-play but it's really more of a base platform for future games (listed as DLC). You get a few cars and less than a handful of tracks to try out, but the rest of it requires money. You should approach this as something like DCS World, where it's used more of a launcher for other games/addons.While the whole pay a metric ♥♥♥♥♥on of money for cars sucks, and something I wish SimBin/Sector3 never did, the actual DLC is topnotch. I wouldn't even call it DLC because the amount of content is equivalent to a whole new game. It still runs on the gmotor/ISImotor engine so graphics aren't the best but it's still stunning and clean. Physics aren't the best and it still feels very gMotor-y, but they still feel amazing to drive and believable. AI reminds me a lot of GTR2, fast, aggressive and (for the most part) clean, they do tend to divebomb from time to time. The thing that stands out the most is the sounds. Hands down the best on the market when it comes to racing sims. You can hear subtle variations in engine tone, track surface, debris and the little squeeks and creaks of your suspension and chassis. You can even tell which tyres are locking up based on sound. Total immersion. It had a really rough (and imo, horrible) start but SimBin finally got their act together and I'm starting to enjoy it more and more. It's not at the level of AC, iR, or rF2 but it's damn good.

												Game looks great but personally I could not get it working with my Logitech GeForce Pro steering wheel. I was like a drunk driver, all over the track. Frame drops and other issus on start of race didn't help.Force Feedback: TOO MANY CONTROLLS on wheel settings plus these settings get changed for every car, So you have to go through the process all over again (most likely) if you change cars. I never felt like I was racing :-(  I also found it impossible to drift due to the problems described with the wheel response and force feedback settings. Maye it's the wheel as I see other people mention the Logitech setups are an issue. I just don't want to spend hrs setting up a wheel for each car I want to use.The grass / track edges seem suck you in. Is that considered realism? I know many games will punish for cutting corners and it should be slippy on the throttle, but should you get sucked into the barrier?

content:
Posted: June 7, 2015
What is Raceroom?Raceroom is in basic english a Raceing Simulator (not meant to be sarcastic).This game is a all round good game, whilst only playing abit on this account most of my testing has been on my games review account (So dont start complaining that 'YOU HAVEN'T PLAYED ENOUGH TO WRITE A REVEIW' Because i have played around 10 hours altogether.)This game is for people that dont want to spend £30 pounds on a racing game and play it evry once in a while, it offers a range of tracks and cars of the less known popular series, you may still end up paying £55 if you really enjoy this game.If you are just getting into racing games, then this game  ISN'T FOR YOU (its like that for a reason), while people wont go out there and then to buy a game wheel and pedels, THIS GAME HATE KEYBOARD AND MOUSE AND STANDARD XBOX OR PLAYSTATION CONTROLLERS (that is also meant to be like that), after many failing attemps of trying to play this game i came to the concluesion to go to my local maplin store and buy some extra peripherals (aka wheel and pedels) i saw a massive improve of how many crashes i was getting.The graphics of this game is good, while this game is 2 years old, my card (which is 5 years old) handles the game pretty well, the shadows are nice with the options to change the day setting which increases or decrease shadows. theres nothing else i can say about this ecept download the game and see for yourself.in concluesion while this game is no project cars it comes close to it, if you are getting started in racing sims and you want to get a feel of what they are like then this is a good game for it otherwise  find another game to make it easier for you i hope this helped in if the game is for you, if it did leave a thumbs up, if it didnt leave a thumbs down and if you think it was funny well Press the funny button.

												This is a Fantastic racing simulator. Very good graphics and over all game play. Be warned for those looking for an arcade like racing game because this is not the game for you then. I am currently using an xbox 360 controller and a ps4 controller (ya i know lol) and they work flawlessly. There is nothing bettter then Pc racing simulators and this is a good one.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 12, 2015
												 This review has to be a very mixed bag. First off let me say I've been with this game from the start. From closed beta till now. I've seen it go from meh.. to a very decent game. Probably one of the best racing titles I've ever played. I always knew that if anybody could get a racing title right it would be these guys. It has the possibilites of blowing GTR 2 out of the water. Yes it could be that good! However there are some very serious issues here. One is the pitstops. Flat after the Oct. 20 patch they don't work. I understand that pitsops in custom championships are coming and that's okay. They weren't originally advertsied to begin with after all. I can live with that. Impatiently but I'll live till then. However it's the broken pitsops in ADAC 2014 experience and DTM 2014 experience that upset me. Can't say about DTM 2015 as I don't own it and from the looks of it I may never. Working pitstops were advertised for the DTM and ADAC 2014 cars. Heck I owned the DTM 2013. It was the only reason to buy the newer set.   In ADAC 2014 the player's car drives straight through the pits without stopping. Resulting in disqualification for not stopping. In DTM 2014 your car stops but the pit doesn't seem to count. You guessed it resulting in your disqualification. These were advertised features. We have to assume they had this worked out before the advertised it , right? Guess not!  There are many other issues and to their credit they working on them. As the recent hotfix suggests but it's not enough. One main quirk if you decide to step into this game, is BEWARE THE PATCHES! They generally break twice as much as they fix. One over the summer brought the whole fool game down. In it's current state I couldn't recommend this game unless you are very patient. And it will be tested, trust me! It is a near brilliant racing title with lot's of racing fun though and if and only if you're willing to hang with it you will love it and hate it and love it and hate it.... You get the picture. I gave this title a thumbs up because it doesn't totally deserve a thumbs down! However you have been warned! As for the 503 errors that everyone is experiencing. I can't say as mine thankfully have been limited. I must be living right or lucky. Also I need to add that I play only single player not multiplayer. So my review can't address any issues there as I haven't seen them. I really would like to give this game a thumbs sideways but can't. Hence the thumbs up.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 22, 2015
												Alot of reviews from people that won't give this game much time - Granted, I spent a good while getting the graphics and feeling (FFB etc) right but you will love it once you find that sweet spot. I find the physics of every car much more alive and engaging than similar vehicles on say, Project Cars or Assetto Corsa, with the force feedback (Using a G27) and the sounds being top notch. Easily the best of any racing sim IMO.The mix of content is fantastic and the track list is a brilliant! - A load of tracks you actually want to drive, not a load of soul-less modern build tracks. Not many games can boast the opportunity to jump from a mental super tuned Zakspeed Capri, to a 2014 WTCC Lada, to a BMW Z4 GT3 then in to a 1992 Audi Quattro DTM. And then choose to take each either up a hillclimb, round Bathurst or to Indianapolis!And the graphics, once dialled up are great. I run a GTX970 and that runs everything maxed. Yet while you can see its a game, everything looks very real.The whole, 'free to play, but each thing costs extra, so you end up spending a tone if you get in to it', idea sucks. But with the prices being no so bad, it could be worst. I could be in to iRacing.Give it a try. Buy some decent content and let the game develop over time as you get in to it and you will love it. The Sector3 forum is a great place to check up on what to expect in future releases aswell and what the team are working on - plus, if you don't like something, post it on there and they will have a look and you never know, they could sort it more to your liking.

content:
Posted: January 28, 2015
												This sim is one of my favorites.Since Sector 3 Studios was born, RaceRoom has received new force feedback, which is acclaimed to be amongst the best. New content has received new physics for cars and new more detailed track surfaces. Also, they are going through all of the old content and updating the cars to the new physics model. Most tracks have now been updated aswell, however they may have finished by the time you read this.Combine these 3 things with genre leading sounds and you have one of the best experiences available in sim racing today.Multiplayer has a unique style of netcode where your ping to each other racer seems to be p2p rather than via the server you are racing on, which is great. Racing standards in most lobbies I have been in is of a good standard.Along side the DLC listed in steam, RaceRoom also has a store in game.The price for cars and tracks beyond the given free ones are very reasonable compared to other sims that charge on a per car/track basis, this also enables the devs to keep adding new content consistently. Content is now available in packs for a discount as well. The neat thing is the way you get a scaling discount based upon how much of said pack you already own. Because I had already bought the DTM packs (DTM 2013 I picked up for a nice $7.50 on sale through steam dlc) and ADAC 2013 pack, when I went to buy the European track pack the remaining 3 or 4 tracks I didn't already own ended up costing me about 20% of what they would have if I bought them individually.One really big thing for me being an Aussie is BATHURST! It's probably the best most accurate version of the track ever made outside of laser scanning.Yep, if you like racing cars with a wheel or even a gamepad, definitely make sure you check this one out.

												Free to Play Racing Sim where you pay for what you want.For some reason this is enough to give the game a negative review. It's worth your time and if you don't like it there's no loss. You don't have to pay a cent.
