number of helpful: 7 of 11 people (64%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 24, 2014
												I got into R3E many months ago, and while my initial thoughts were negative, I opted to wait and see where SimBin (at the time) were going to go with this title especially as a fan of their earlier titles primarily Race 07 and GTR 2.While initially it suffered from a stagnant development period, the new Sector3 and their current contributions have vastly improved this title to become my now go-to racing sim, with vast improvements in the areas of physics, force feedback, single player and multi-player and the constant rate new content is pushed out.While graphics are impressive, other simulators such as Assetto Corsa or Project Cars lead in this area, not to say that Sector3 have done an outstanding job on their engine with impressive HDR, bloom and dynamic lighting effect. SimBin/Sector3 has always been a leader in bringing the driver the most realistic sound experience in all their titles, and this continues with R3E.With the last major update, Sector3 have done a major overhaul of the force feedback system. Their track developers have developed a new technology to improve the presentation and feedback of their track’s road surface utilising data from telemetry to create a highly dense road surface that features small bumps and imperfections in the surface the increases the quality of the force feedback immensely.AI does leave plenty of room for improvement, while R3E supposably utilises an “Adaptive AI”, I find many times, AI will run up the back of you like a solid lead block, causing a frustrating racing experience at the best of times with little to no effect on themselves.Content is plentiful, with a range of cars and tracks with new content currently added recently including the ADAC 2013 GT Masters Pack and the WTCC 2013 Pack including tracks as part of each package. Still, the biggest question mark is the pricing system, while I have noticed and taken advantage of the pack discounts, standard pricing is on the expensive side. I personally would advise to hold off for specials or car packs prior to purchasing content if you consider yourself the collector, or buy one car in each class as needed. With the new inclusion of the new “Test Drive” feature, you will be able to make a sound decision prior to purchase regardless of the price.As a free to play game, this title is worth the time to experience the improvements that Sector3 have made to bring this sim up to the standard that many sim racers will look for. If you're willing to part with your cash to race new cars on new tracks, then you will enjoy a race or two, whether its a against the AI, online multiplayer with friends, or a quick hotlapping session.

number of helpful: 7 of 11 people (64%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 29, 2014
												Overall, I like this game. I, to be honest, expected something along the lines of Forza or Grand Torismo standards, but in my eyes, it met a fraction of those standards. I have to admit though, this is a very nice and sharp looking game when it's on it's highest settings (it set mine to the highest setting because my computer is very powerful). I am very fond of how many cars there are in the game and I love how each and every one of them has their own different sound. Although i'm not a car expert, if fact I don't really know much about cars in the first place....but I still wanted to try this game as I have heard it looked amazing and was a very good free to play game. They were right. Although this game has a lot of good stuff about it, I feel it has quite a lot of negative stuff about it. To start off, I noticed how there was a MAJOR lack of music unlike Forza or Grand Torismo or most racing games combined. This really annoys me because I feel that the music can bring a certain video game to life (ex: Saints Row 3, I actually got hooked on it because I started listening to it's soundtrack and just fell in love). I also didn't like how a good 75% of controls are unbinded at default, which I don't know if that's because the developers just wanted to let the player bind them his/herself or because they were just too lazy. Another problem is with every single car. What I noticed is how they all fail to break especially on very hard turns. I always find myself in 5-6th gear and then a very hard turn comes and I slow down, but I slow down enough that i'm still in 3rd-4th gear which doesn't help with the turn (I stop nearly 2 seconds before the actual turn). This is also a problem because I don't know if I properly binded a key; handbrake. I binded it to space (it shows I binded it correctly in the settings, but i'm just not sure) and when I press space while the car is just rolling, nothing happens. If I use it when i'm turning, slight to nothing really happens. In most case senarios I feel it does virtually nothing, when compared to other racing games where the handbrake is vital to the game. Handbrake wasn't even pre-binded when I started the game. Set aside all the negative stuff about the game, I would like to focus on the positive stuff in the game. What I think I enjoy the most about this is how it's actually more of a formula one racing game as you don't see day-to-day cars in the game like Forza. I personally love the formula one cars because they always give me a sence of how it would really feel if I was in one. With a computer so heavily powered and with a game that looks so amazing as this one does, they make up well to fulfill what I like most about formula one cars. I also like how there are LOTS of cars and tracks to choose from (there aren't many default and free tracks and cars, but there are a TON of paid tracks and cars). Although I don't have a lot of time under my belt playing the game, I can see it will turn out to be a very well made game. 7.9/10

content:
Posted: July 28, 2015
												I'm conflicted over RRE - overall I've had a lot of fun so I give it's a 'recommended' but it's a mixed bag.Good pointsMost of the cars are beautifully modelled, looking and (importantly) sounding great.Handling is mostly top-notch Tracks are well modelled (tho Bathurst lacks the bumps it has in reality and Brands is Indy only)Bad PointsThe AI isn't the best - it's not keen to overtake, seems to have MUCH better brakes/grip and hitting/being hit by an AI car tends to result in it carrying-on and you being thrown into the scenery.The pricing model means the odds are your mates won't have the cars/tracks you do which limits online fun a bitI don't really mind the 'free game - pay for cars and tracks' model overall - it encourages them to keep developing the game by keeping the money coming in.Tips:Cars are cheaper on their own rather that in packs UNLESS you want all the LIVERIES (which make-up most of the cost)Just because you don't own a car/livery doesn't mean the AI/other players can't use it in races (you won't be racing all-the-same cars even if you only own 1 car/livery in a class)Adaptive AI doesn't really work (for me at least) - just dial-in your level and you'll have more funTest-drive any car you like from the Store (one track only but you'll get the idea)Steam Sales offer cheap DLC packs!!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 27, 2015
												I can't recommend this game enough. Sure it has it's foibles, but it is a game still in development and the pros far outweigh the cons.+ Stunning sounds, everything from backfires to suspension tweaks, from transmission flex to wind buffeting.+ Great graphics. Only DX9 sure, but wonderful lighting and colour.+ Good physics. A little more forgiving than perhaps it should be, but they do use race driver feedback, and it makes it more accessible.+ Awesome content. Unless you like open-wheelers, then the content is stunning, from DTM to Group 5, from WTCC to GT Masters.+ You can try out any car before buying it, which is an awesome feature.- The pay model has its benefits and it's disadvantages. Firstly, you only have to buy what you want, which means you can in theory pay less than a normal 'all-up front' game, in which I often find I don't use all the content anyway. The disadvantage is that it is on the expensive side for sure, though much cheaper than iRacing and there is no monthly subscription. You also only need one car from any group of cars to be able to compete with the others, like iRacing.- The servers are still not stable, but is something they are working on, and is improving at a decent rate.- Would be better if the circuits were laser-scanned, though the upcoming Nordschleife will be.

Sound, gfx and speeeed :D This is really an experience!For some months i have turned my back and was in iRacing and Loeb Rally. Now after the last patch - 31/3/2016 - my racer heart is pumping stronger :D Nordschleife is out!The new Nordschleife is a beauty and huuugggeee fun to race online with enough racers! - (btw I prefer online racing).R3E gives you an amount of content, AI-racing is becoming better and better and you have the mp-part - which lacks of some features so far. Check it out! Absolute worth it!For more infos visit the devs-forum:https://forum.sector3studios.com/index.php?find-new/1901361/postsHave fun!HarryoPS: Leave the FOV on 1.0 - real FOV cockpit view - and change the seat-position to your liking. content:
Posted: March 12, 2014
												This is a great sim with lots of potential but will not get a lot of followers in its present state due to it having no multiplayer function.  Although it's classed as a free to play game it really isn't.  You get a couple of cars and the odd track for free but for anything else you're going to have to dig deep.  You are expected to purchase VP points for real cash and then exchange your VP points to purchase cars and tracks.  This can empty your pockets to the tune of hundreds of £.  On top of this they have other 'purchase to play' addons called 'Experiences'.  At present there is the 'DTM Experience' which bolts on to the RRE  menus but runs a full DTM 2013 season against AI.....again, with no Multiplayer.  This comes at the cost of a full game and is basically what seasoned sim racer would call a mod of RRE.  The next "Experience" to come along will be the British or World Touring Car Championship in which you will be expected to shell out another 20-30 £ or Euros for.  While this is all going on you cannot use the tracks from DTM experience is the standard game of RRE.  No no no, you have to buy the tracks again even though they already exist in the DTM Experience.  Even though this is a fairly decent sim it looks like Simbin will contnue to milk you for every penny they can and I for one will turn to better (And much cheaper) simulators like Assetto Corsa and rFactor 2 as they have an active modding community which provide free content as well as being able to share tracks can be between mods etc.A great game spoilt by a rabid thirst for your money.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 15, 2015
												Know what you're getting into.It's obvious a lot of effort went into this game; the realism is fantastic. However, be warned that with a high level of realism in the physics and handling comes a higher difficulty, or at least a much steeper learning curve. The game is probably much better when played on a wheel, but with a standard controller you're probably gonna have a frustrating time. I know I did. If you live and breathe racing sims and don't mind taking the time to learn how to control the monstrously powerful cars in this game, go for it. If you're looking for a relaxing blast through the tracks with a more arcade-y feel, this definitely isn't the game for you. Track and car selection is limited without paying, and it would be nice if all of the free cars were grouped in one list so you didn't have to search around, but pay-to-play stuff like this comes with the territory with free games. tl;dr: This game treats racing as SRS BUSINESS, be prepared.

												Great game. I've played Forza, GT...love GT6, but damn! Raceroom is fun. I bought the WTCC addon (but I love WTCC) and it's a blast to drive. The FWD physics is awesome...awesome = realistic durining corning and hard braking. Then I bought the GT3 addon (everything was bought during Xmas sales) and it was a blast, I still need traction control but perfection comes with time (plus i'm using the xbox controller). Buying  some of the tracks is a bit lame, to be honest but that's how this developer pays their employees. I use a 8 core AMD , 32 gbs o' ram with 2 gtx 760's...more than enough for this game. It runs AMAZING. If you love racing give this a shot and get the some of the addons while their still on xmas discount.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 10, 2015
												This Game is awesome.  The physics are superb for a free game.  You do only get 3 tracks, but the hours of gameplay you can make with just the free stuff is endless.  Custom Championships Races against actually good AI or Adaptive AI.  The sounds on the game is basically ear porn.  The engines sound amazing.  No over the top tire screech or very loose "I'm driving on ice" simulation.For anyone who does not have a Controller, or a Wheel.  There are settings for keyboard users to make your driving just how you would want it. Steering sensitivity, Throttle sensitivity, Brake sensitivity, Clutch sensitivity ETC.. just for keyboard driving.Honestly If you enjoy Racing Simulator's,  Its FREE and worth your time. (5 hours in and I'm still fully enjoying the game)EDIT:  I am using a Logitech F310 Gaming Controller now with this game. And it works very well.  Just as you can adjust all your sensitivity for a keyboard you can do the same for the Controller.DOUBLE EDIT: The game works fantastic with a Logitech G29

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 15, 2015
												With each and every update this game just keeps getting better and better , RRE competes on every level with any AAA title released to date , this game in my opinion is fast becoming a work of art , graphically and technically RRE has exceeded all my expectations and cannot be overlooked by any sim racer. The driving experience is very realistic and suited to players of all levels. The UI is particularly nice and offers everything you could possibly think you want, options are really well laid out in a manner which suits the whole presentation package perfectly,  a lot of work and thought has went into this title and anyone who loves attention to detail will no doubt agree, this is one of the very best sim racers available on PC , ( if not the best ). RRE also has some of the best force feed back and FFB options I have experienced in any racing title.Simply Awesome 10/10 a must have sim.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2015
												I've owned Raceroom for a couple of years now. Originally, I was put off with the lack of cars and tracks, and the price of the DLC but I've bought it when on a steam sale. I own rFactor 2, Project Cars, Stock Car Extreme and Assetto Corsa and this game feels as good to drive as any of the others. Maybe not quite as good, physics wise, as rFactor 2 or Assetto Corsa, but it looks wonderful, as nice as Project Cars.I feel that this Racing Sim is a little underrated and doesn't get the credit it deserves.Plus points:Runs at well over 100 ( nearer 200 ) fps on my system! ( i5 4670k, 16gb ram, Nvidia Geforce 970 gtx, Acer 144mhz monitor. )Wonderful force feedback with my Logitech G27 wheel.Looks lovely, tracks, sky, cars, reflections, very nice indeed.Great leaderboard challenge mode.If you alter car settings you can feel the difference.Online races can be very good, with less "console racers" than on Project Cars.Idiot drivers are turned into ghosts automatically by the game, so they don't ruin everyone elses race!Minus points.DLC can be expensive.Game is threadbare unless you're willing to purchase some DLC.Online games are hard to find without DLC.Plenty of online servers are empty.Overall, this game is great fun.I would recommend downloading the barebones version to start with, if you enjoy the couple of free cars and tracks then it's well worth considering buying some DLC.8/10

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2015
												Absolutely f***** fantastic!!!!If you want to race real racing cars and not mess about thrashing road cars then this is for you!As for all the negative feedback, yes! it is getting expensive as ive spent around £30 quid on this sim so far, however! What the negative feedback fails to mention is this, YOU CAN TEST DRIVE ANY CAR FOR FREE!!! You do only get a few tracks to start with, but now you seem to get a whole load more cars for free, trust me its worth spending some time with this sim just for the sound and the free test driving..... hop in the Ford Capri Race Car, I spent and hour test driving it simply for the insane noise it makes, id short shift most of the time and then treat myself to the odd high rev just to hear the engine, it actually gave me goose bumps!So then the physics.......... all I need to say here is that actual real racing drivers use this as training, TIMO GLOCK is one name that springs to mind, his profile in game reveals over 4 days of gameplay haha. Yes its a hard game to master and I'm a long way off, if I'm lucky I can get in the top 30% on a leaderboard and ive been playing these games/sims for over 15 years.Graphics are not the greatest but you get the feeling more of the processing power is being used on the physics engine than on processing eye candy. Real sense of rubber and tarmac like you used to get with RACE07.And the sound..... once again its worth throwing a few quid at this title just for the sound. Its sexy.

Posted: February 5, 2015
												The game is pretty fun, although the community is some what lacking but the online and single player modes are on par which is great! Connectivity to the servers is great and no one is bouncing around in the air and touching down out of nowhere in front of you. I can't feel the road or what the car is going to do, it feels like I'm driving a prius with a sound system made to make it sound like a race car. The road is numb, you can't feel the surface of the road and the cars are very unforgiving - but this is a beta so I won't discourage you from trying it. It's a fun game and I like the layout of the menu's and how you can edit your settings to your preference i.e deadzones, sensativity etc. Keep it up, I might actually drop the cash for a wheel and see what the game is really worth.

content:
Posted: September 7, 2015
												This is a fantastic racing sim.  It is not an arcade game, it is not Gran Turismo or Need for Speed.  To get the most out of this game will require a wheel and pedal set.  It is free but only comes with basic content, the rest is paid but it is enough to try it out -  more content is very reasonable and there are no microtransactions or subscription.Players include professional race car drivers.  To be the fastest person he will take a lot of doing.  Not really for people who don't love driving race cars and don't mind being beaten a lot.  There are no street cars in this game.  There are ongoing competions and many many hotlap leaderboards.I have been sim racing for a long time and at the moment this and Game Stock Car are all I want to play.If you play this for 6 minutes with a keyboard and then hate it because you are struggling instead of winning everything in sight as on an EA game leaving a bad review is unfair.  Note that these people are in the multiplayer on the free content and if you are worried the other multiplayer is a lot cleaner although there is no safety rating system as yet.If you like driving realistic race cars get this game.

content:
Posted: April 3, 2016
												I noticed that most people who did a negative review of this game played less than 1 hour ......If you ever like'd Race 07 , gtr , gtr2 etc etc , you like this game also .I first bought me a car to get out of the open servers  and found a bunch of people who liked racing!! There are always some servers with atleast 7 / 10 people around.. Tracks are nice and the physics & force feedback are great , not to difficult to drive fast but to get that last second of you'r time you have to practise..Default setups are not far off pace and enough to have a decent race with and be not the one at the back of the field.After a while i bought me the packs i wanted and a few single cars to participate in online races in almost every class there is .So if you only like to drive online against other players the costs are not much more or equal as any other racing game.btw  , single races with the purchased cars are possiblle (even championships) and you get the whole field of cars to that class (not driveable) for free so you don't race 25 the same cars that you have ( buy 1 gt3 and the whole gt3 pack race's with you) :)  Great !So next time you buy a beer in a bar ,  you have to think that that beer also could have been a nice GT3 in this game ...Ohw yeah...  BUY A WHEEL !!!  and try again after your negative revieuw .... this is a SIM..

content:
Posted: July 30, 2016
												It was good, but requires MONEY to buy a racing simulator gear. $350 for a decent wheel and pedals. At least another grand for simulator frame. I already have the surround sound system (including 5.1 speakers), but only because I got those cheap long time ago. Racing simulators are the best games ever created, but playing them is just expensive. I'm an engineer making good money, but with kids going to college soon how am I supposed to afford a hobby? They just ask for more and more. And I still have student loans, a drinking habit (microbrews, expensive as hell), car payments, high speed internet, etc to pay for. Nothing left to spend on a racing rig. Fence needs completion too. At least $200 more for pickets and nails. Brother has a nail gun so that helps. Then you have all the richy riches on the web, playing the ladders and sticking in times like they had a professional racing gear. It's just not fair. I'd take any of them on on equal setting. I'd probably raced these games before they were born. But there is no place in town to actually do that. I guess I'll come back to it in about 10 years when the kids have their own money to spend, and I have mine.

content:
Posted: July 4, 2014
												Raceroom is a great racing simulator. It has good physics and graphics, and AMAZING sounds. Simbin has done a great job capturing the feel. Now, the downside I'm goign to point out is that this is not entirely free to play. It is essentially a base game with a couple cars and tracks. Extra tracks and cars must be bought. Raceroom is constantly being updated with new content, if you want to buy stuff wait until it goes on sale. Everything eventually will go on sale for at least %50 off. If you ever need any input the raceroom discussion board is a great place as well. ==In Short==: Awesome Racing Sim, but Not Truly FTP.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 25, 2015
												This is the best sim since Grand Prix Legends. Simply the most fun you can have with your clothes on. Period. If you love race cars & racing this is as close as you can get to the real thing. They even give you a couple of tracks &  3 cars for free, Whats to complain about. Yes Multiplayer is in alpha. So if you do that then you can expect problems. But the single player game is great against the ai. Works fine & is stable on my Pc. Try it. You won't be disapointed. But as said by others. Buy your upgrades direct from the games website. Not through Steam. You can purchace from your steam wallet. It's not perfect yet there still working on it. But it is good.... Very good! Bought some tracks including one I've actually driven on & it's spot on. When you crash it doesn't even cost you anything!!!! Hell I love this game already & I only had it a few days! Works well with a joystick. So you don't have to spend a fortune on a wheel. Now I've got the thing calibrated good bye life...... :-) Sure if your looking for arcade forget it. You will hate it. Go and waste your money on something else. Bore your brains out after 15 hours. This will take you that long to get into it. Trust me I'm only just starting. This can only get better, With more tracks coming online all the time it will be alot better. And when they sort the multiplayer........... Bought 7 tracks & 20 cars for £20 so don't believe the doom merchants. Much cheaper from the games website than on steam, This is one game I don't mind paying for DLC''s as it will keep the game in developement. Real world physics. Awesome sound that deserves some decent speakers. And after all they give you so much for free. How you can whinge about that. If it doesn't work on your system then at least it hasn't cost you anything. I have paid good money for other race games that won't even run on my Pc or have no controller support. This game is quality.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 24, 2015
												R3E was absolutely terrible not so long ago. The interface was a nightmare and the racing odd with the huge coloured markers etc. If you judge it on that, let me tell you that it's now a completely different game.The interface now makes sense, and is one of the best you'll find out there. The game is F2P with purchases for content (but the ability to enter certain events without purchasing the content and the option to try before you buy). There are frequent sales so you don't have to spend a fortune.Cars are very impressive with the physics being better than iRacing, Project Cars and Assetto Corsa but not quite as good as RFactor 2. Tracks, while not laser scanned, are not too far off the quality of RF2's non-laser-scanned tracks. The geometry is generally accurate, but of course you don't get the exact bumps, but laser scans quickly become out of date so this isn't as big an issue as one might expect. Sounds are the best you'll find anywhere, really expressing the clunky rattling shaking madness of a real race car.Netcode needs a bit of work [cars behave strangely with high pings and disconnects happen], but multiplayer is in alpha I believe, so hopefully that'll improve in time. The usual issues of only 30% finishing and loads of wrecks apply in public servers but plenty of leagues exist to cater to the more serious racer. Single-player features the most enjoyable AI I've raced against.In short, R3E is VASTLY better than it was, and now deserves a place among the elite of sim-racing.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 24, 2015
												This game is a good start to driving sims. If you picked up your brand new 900-1080 degree FFB wheel and you got no money left over, look no further than this gem. The physics are on par with the lazer scaned iracing, and super car fun fest Asseto Corrsa. The begining cars and tracks are fun to learn, and really give you a sense of joy when shaving off 1/4 a second of a hotlap all while realizing how this is meaningless. There are 3 main modes of difficulty: Novice- Babies first racing sim, Amateur- X360 gamepad user, and Get Real- Why am I backwards and why is my front end smashed in? The only complaint is that the DLC is not only hard on the conusmer, it makes finding servers a living hell. The full experiece will cost you upwards of $100 and it is hard to justify that when other games cost around $50 and have the same content.

content:
Posted: December 12, 2015
												I laugh at people complaining about poor optimisation. I run this on an i7 2600k with 16GB DDR3 1600Mhz RAM and 2 780ti gpu in sli at 3440 x 1440 with 20 to 30 cars on grid and average 60 to 80 fps with graphics on max on windows 10.The game itself is ok and can be fun, granted the handling is average but it is fun. By no means is it a sim, thats another discussion, but if you enjoy driving and have a wheel or controller (the game is controller friendly) then you will enjoy this. Only issue is the dlc but if your sensible and wait for dlc sale in the in game store, you can pickup content as you go for a reasonable price.RRE isnt my go to driivng game, but it is good enough that I do keep coming back to it.

content:
Posted: June 27, 2015
												great racing sim. wide selection of detailed cars/classes and courses that are updated quite frequently. offciall DTM, WTCC, ADAC series, with all cars, liveries and tracks. amazing sound. FFB is great, strong, detailed and realistic. the settings are not too complicated to adjust to personal taste.people complain about it being not being free...of course it isn't, but you pay for what you are interested in, and there are always things on sale.overall, one of my favorite sims. the devs are always improving it and adding new content.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 19, 2016
												Free to play is demo mode, that is what Sector3 needs to fix for less negativity, end of story.Cheaper than iRacing and probably one of the best racing sims at the moment.Helpful comunity on their forums, found a good guide for my CSW v.2, tweaked them a bit to my preferences, FFB feels great and immersive, probably if not the best compared to other sims once the right configuration settings are found.Didn't change much ingame but basically had to turn almost everything off on my csw.Best part is "Get Real", the cars and tracks behave more realistic than in any other Sim/racing game I tried.Soundgasm, cars sound like they should sound.Graphics aren't the latest but still looks pretty good, there are some newer comparisons between RRE, AC, PC and iRacing on youtube, just look for "Raceroom Nordschleife Comparison 2016" to get some of the most recent.RRE doesn't have a lot bloat filters, simple and clean, like it should be for any racing sim/game.There are few cons:1. Can't map the main menu navigation to wheel buttons, there should be no need for mouse navigation, or at least it should be a choice.2. Can't create a single player championship that is saved for later, no one will drive a full length championship without resting.3. Needs people to move over from the dark side :DAs for people yapping about that the sim requires them to be online, there are surely some validations etc. going on to avoid cheats, keep in mind what RRE tries to compete against.And if it realy is a must Sector3 sells DVD versions which can be played offline.

content:
Posted: December 10, 2015
												I do recommend this game because to me it feels very genuine, and especially the track layouts are very accurate. The graphics are fantastic, except for the surroundings of the track, but who really cares about that...?It's fun, lot to discover, tracks to learn, cars to handle and the buyable content is a very smart move by the producer,(because you'll want more and more content each priced quite fairly) but also for the customer to spend as much or as little as he himself desires. Good game! I'm looking forward to even more classes and tracks in the future.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 26, 2013
												A great free to play simulator.  It has better graphics than Simraceway, and the sound quality is seccond to none!  This is the level of quality I have come to expect from a great publisher like SIMBIN and this is no exception.  The physics model is continually updated and they now even simulate transmission wear!  There is also a chance to try out each and every car before you buy it.  I wish the same could be said for tracks; however, once again, SIMBIN is more generous than most, if not all, in this category.  Even if you are skeptical, try it out.  If you don't like it, uninstal it.  I highly reccomend this to everyone from sim junkies to those who just want an upgrade from Need For Speed.  The highly customizable dificulty threshold means that RaceRoom is a simulator which you can grow with and (crucially, for me) does not continually hemmoarge your wallet (cough, cough, iRacing) during the process.  Unlike many games, you truly have nothing to lose beyond a few minutes of your time.  In my case, I wasn't dissapointed in the slightest.

content:
Posted: July 10, 2015
												READ THIS.Before you download this 15gb game consider this:Do you like Quantity, or Quality?Quality? RaceRoom Racing Experience (R3E). Newer, better native support. If you play it though, expect having to dish out the dough for getting a amazing experience. $40 dollars can get you (if stuff is on sale, which is regularly is) 10-15 tracks, and 5-10 cars, some in "packs." The physics is great, the controls are amazing (I'm on a XBOX 360 controller), and the game just feels perfect. Personally I love the competitions of where its just you and the track and you try to get the best time out of EVERYONE. But you have to pay for everything.-vs-Quantity? Race07. Older game, but still holds up to date, if you want this game, get the SimBin Mega Bundle (same $40 dollars!) and get all the DLC and its 15$ less then buying all of them alone. The game has it's quirks and could have been better but is still an amazing racing game none-the-less. But it has loads and I mean LOADS of tracks and a nice array of cars.You choose, and don't go hating on this game. It's certainly a different approach to paying into a game, but it is OK SimBin, OK.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 15, 2015
												First off let me say, Im a HUGE fan of project cars... That being said..I just got this game today and for this being early access and only having 5 cars and 3  tracks (with about 4-6 variations on each track) to start off freely... THIS GAME IS AMAZING. The physics and force feedback on my G27 are just spot on.1. Graphics - 8/10 - There are prettier games out there.. but lets face it.. its early access and they still look great.2. Sound - 10/10.. Ive never heard such satisfying superchargers, turbos and crunching suspensions in a game to this day.3. Physics - 10/10 - Somehow they really make you feel every little bump, dip and lateral movement better than any racing game i've played to date.4. Car Setup - 7/10 - This is the only part that feels lacking, Being early acess we can only hope it improves.5. Multiplayer -10/10 Ive played it all morning and loved every minute of it. There are of course all the drivers who do not have respect for others, im sure its just the flood of "free to play" players trying the game out. Its very competetive in real sim mode with no racing lines available making you pay close attention to your speed and braking points. Have not tried novice and ameture mode so can offer no comment if racing line is available at all.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 15, 2015
												I downloaded this game at the beginning of the weekend, and I'm glad I did! Awesome free content. Although there's only a few cars to race with, you can try any of the cars in the game for free. There's only a few tracks for free, plenty more if you want to pay.  So far, using the free cars  and the free tracks, I'm definitely hooked! The sound effects are great, the cars sound like the real deal. Far better than most racing games, and in some ways, better than any racing game I've ever played. Yeah, it's that good! The physics are excellent, and you are given 3 choices for general set-up, abs,tcs,etc. I've found a happy medium with the middle choice, it lets me learn the cars and tracks easier. The tracks are beautiful, and have lots of elevation change, rumble strips, run-offs, etc. Again, I've personally only played on three of the tracks. I really like how you can set-up your race with practice and qualifying. This is something that seems lost on console racing games. My only real gripe thus far is the Ai. I've been racing with the adaptive Ai, which for one race was ridiculously easy, then the next race very hard. And going with that was the aggression of the Ai, when I braked a little earlier for a turn and got rear ended and booted from the track. Really? Sometimes damage seems to happen, other times, you can drive into a wall with no consequences. Glitch? But, gripes aside, this is a really well made game, and for free? Amazing! I will most likely end up buying more content when I get bored with the free stuff. I still can't get over the sounds!...

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 16, 2015
												So, I've played it for a little bit, and it's fun.  There are only a few cars, and a few tracks, unless you're down to spend money, but that's fine with me.  I don't know about the game modes, I just play time trials and try and beat myself.  The cars which you have access to are quite powerful, and the sense of speed feels inaccurate - but could be that I'm used to games with more world detail, allowing for more points of reference thus a better perception of speed.  Handling feels great, I don't feel that I had to adjust much - if at all - from the way I drive Codemasters games like Grid and DiRT [I think they make DiRT??  Yeah, pretty sure...].  RaceRoom doesn't seem to offer anything that any of the paid-for games I posess fail to present themselves, however I'll leave it on my drive and hope they update with some more free content.  The build I played, I only recall the cars and tracks for sale and no ads.EDIT:  Oh, duh, and it works GREAT with my Logitech Driving Force Pro or GT or whatever it is.  They allow you to fully customize all kinds buttons, which is neat.  The hill climb in the BMW is a ton of fun, I really like that track.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 1, 2015
												I've been a bit critial of RR prevoiusly, but I just played WTCC 2013 and I have to say, wow one of the best single player experiences I've had in a sim. I own a good bit of RR content, but these cars feel the best out of the lot..... great job on the physics  and the AI is brilliantly done! Over all:Physics - B+ for WTCC cars (other GT cars are spotty)Graphics - meh C+Sound - A+AI - A (amazing AI) Overall, well worth the 12 bucks I paid... what a bargan.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 3, 2015
												Not going to write a lenghty review, but to the people who are saying the business model is 'bad' are wrong. It is what I would call flexible. Sure, there isn't much base content, and I think Sector3 Studios should offer another car and track combo to really get a feel for what this game has to offer.The cars are relatively cheap (can be even cheaper if bought in packs) and are all quality-made. Same goes for the tracks, minus a few inaccuracies here and there. Most notably is track elevation, this game does not seem to create the feeling of elevation too well when compared with other sims such as rFactor, Assetto Corsa and of course iRacing.You are not forced to pay hundreds of dollars, you can simply do as I have done and buy 6-8 cars and a few tracks. That's it. I will be entertained for a few weeks with just this little bit of content as I practice to get the most out of each car and track I drive.Thank you for taking the time to read the short review!

content:
Posted: March 30, 2013
												A very good free to play racing game that could be a bit better in control. What it lacks in fluid controls though is forgiven for its great amount of detail that SimBin put into the environments and cars. The biggest problem though is that you must be online at all times and only about three to four cars and courses are available to you right away. The other cars and courses must be bought in order to use them. Other than that this game is a great download for those who enjoy games like Gran Turismo or Forza Motorsport.

content:
Posted: March 15, 2014
												After I dialed in my FFB and Degrees of rotation properly, I was hooked. To me, the graphics are beautiful. The physics are fantastic. The sound is obviously amazing. I just want my AI single player experience already. But this sim feels, sounds, and looks very good; and once its fully finished (if ever) I'll be spending many YEARS with it. Just dial in your settings correctly and you'll see what I mean. My FFB is set to just 27 strength and the FFB effects are set to full with 400 degrees of rotation set to BOTH - my Fanatec Porsche GT3 wheel AND in game. Can't wait to race you guys!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 5, 2014
												As a simracing beginner I have to say that I like this title. The feeling of the car is very good and the sound is just awesome. I can not describe how good and realistic it is. The apex hunt feature has helped me as a beginner to reduce my lap times and learn the tracks and breaking points. Ok there are some negative points aswell, such as missing night/day features, weather and multiplayer. Another negative point is that if you want all of the content such as tracks, cars and liveries, you better start saving up some money because it is very expensive. The overall image is good I think but not perfect. It is a developing product so it is improved with every update and the fact that it is more or less free to play ( you can drive 2 cars on one track and participate in challenges) should encourage everyone to at least try it out. I would highly suggest it for those who are simracing beginners or for those who want to see if they like simracing or not.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 22, 2014
												This game seems to be following the iRacing model of managing content, as in you get a little bit for free, then anything else requires purchase. There are free events though that allow you access to content you may not yet own, and prizes are offered for competitions in-game. It looks and sounds great, handles pretty well, and offers a good range of content. The freshly-released Multiplayer Alpha for the DTM Experience is good, although as with almost any online racing game, the majority of drivers are incapable of clean racing, often resorting to blocking, ramming and all that. Also at the moment the sessions appear to be fixed in format, and I haven't seen private sessions.Overall, you will have to put money into this unless you are talented enough to be a prize winner, but it is definitely enjoyable, even with the free content. Very much recommend that you at least give it a try.

content:
Posted: April 21, 2013
												I think this game is one to watch. It really is a very high quality racing simulator especially considering it is free. A little too far down the realism spectrum for my liking though. The main problem is that there is no sense of accomplishment or incentive to keep playing. In most racing games you win races to unlock new tracks and cars which keeps you wanting to play on. But here you unlock new stuff by buying it. Also the races them self are just against the clock. There is very little sense of accomplishment from just moving a few places up the leader boards. So as I say I think this is one to keep an eye on as more content become available.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 12, 2014
												*** German translation in comments section / Deutsche Übersetzung als Kommentar ***First of all, my review is based on playing R3E with a wheel (Fanatec GT3RS v2 + Clubsport Pedals v1) and in "GetReal"-mode only. So the FFB + physics part may not match the driving experience of gamepad users. The driving at other difficulty levels (Novice or Amateur) may also differ.Graphics:The overall graphics are quite nice, but sometimes the whole scenery looks a little bit "cartoony". Maybe it lacks better shaders to give the graphics a more real touch. Nevertheless i like the graphics, but improvements are always welcome.The available tracks are well-made. As a sidenote .... i like the swaying trees. These small details adds to immersion.Big immersion breaker: The big colored distance markers!I hope Simbin brings us an option soon to replace these arcade-style signs with realistic corner/brake/distance markers.Sound:Actually R3E has the best sound of all available Simracing titles (incl. the Simulations in beta-, alpha-, pre-alpha-status). But iRacing and pCARS are on the way to close the gap (or are on par with some cars). It seems that more and more developer have recognized now the important role of realistic sounds to improve the immersion.Just a small point of criticism: In external TV-cam the engine should be a little bit louder and lasts longer on departure.Force Feedback:IMHO the FFB is one of the things which needs to improve in R3E. The whole system with different "FFB effects level" and its canned effects is kinda old school. It seems that there's too much "ancient" ISI-motor stuff in use. (BTW ... Reiza Studios demonstrate greatly with Game Stock Car 2013 what is still possible with the aged physics engine)The FFB effects should come right from the physics (suspension + tires). Just like RealFeel-FFB or/and LeoFFB plugins for rFactor. All these canned effects e.g. for rumblestrips aren't necessary, if the FFB would come direct from the physics. Furthermore some of these canned effects settings makes it more difficult to get the FFB feel right.Also the default controller files aren't that good out-of-the-box. For most players it is necessary to play with all the FFB parameters to find some settings, whereby you feel comfortable with. And there are a lot of these FFB parameters, which actually aren't accessable via the GUI. It might be not an easy "Start & Race" and this could discourage R3E newcomers.Physics:Goes a little bit hand in hand with the FFB. If the FFB is badly configured you can't get the right feel for the car/physics. But if you find some good settings for your wheel, then the physics come to live too.A few times the word "simcade" was mentioned within the community. I'm not agree with that. Many of us are used to the older sims (e.g. GTR2, rFactor1, etc.) and its kind of "low grip feeling", which makes you believe that race cars are very difficult to drive. But that's not the case. Race cars are well balanced and build to give you tons of grip, and not to kill the driver in every corner. Only driving on the limit makes it difficult and will separate the winners from the losers. ;) I think that R3E has implemented this grippy track feeling very well. That's not a reason to call R3E not a sim (or "simcade").Multiplayer:Not yet available. Only leaderboard challenges where you can race against ghost cars (recorded by other players) are possible at the moment.Furthermore there are actually almost no official informations about the planned multiplayer features for R3E.F2P, Content & Pricing:Free2Play but actually not much free content. Even if there are almost constantly competitions and try-before-you-buy events, but a little more free stuff would be good.Referring to the not-free content, i think the prices for cars and tracks are quite fair. You can drive a car for years and have much fun on a well-made track, and now compare it with the small fee you must pay for it. Otherwise .... if you want all the tracks and cars, it might become very very expensive. I would like to see some bundled packs as special offer from Simbin.What i didn't like is the Livery-part. I have always liked to paint my own car skins. Now i have to pay for a livery and the available real liveries do cost too much. And if you buy a car, i would appreciate that 2-3 liveries (different ones and not only a changed numberplate) are included at least, just to have a basic choice. Look at the leaderboards ........ almost every driver is driving the provided standard livery. And now imagine some multiplayer races later on, where almost everyone is driving the same car skin.

content:
Posted: July 4, 2014
												This is pure simulator with almost none of virtual help, it's all up to you and your driving style, I love that in simulators when they just put you in action and leave you to learn about the game through the gameplay. When I started playing I thought this game is all about paying for extra stuff. Yea, it is expensive as hell, but its a good game. Sure, only 1 fictional track for use is terrible. The sound is awesome and so are the physics.First feel: 6/10Gameplay: 9/10Controller support: 9/10Physics 9/10 - Driving: 10/10                      Crashing physics: 10/10                      Crash damage: 3/10 Sound: 11/10Price: 3/10Overall game experience: 9/10 - Very fun but very expensive and a lot of locked stuff ruins the fun gameplay. Especially if you have to pay for every car and track.Edit: Most of the competitions lend you everything neccessery for racing, so you can explore new cars and tracks. That feature is very good.

content:
Posted: January 17, 2016
												Bottom line here , Good game , cars , tracks , sound all good , its a sim not arcade type racer , yes you need to buy the tracks and cars you want to race ,Yes people moan about paying for the cars and track here is my point of view.Other games your pay "x" amount for the base game , then pay normally more for the DLC's that follow , Here you are getting the base game , you get a few cars and tracks all for free , you can practise on those to get a feel for things , Go test drive the different disiplines and decide which disiplline you would like to follow as a carreer , then go ahead and purchase that disiplin and track pack for the chosen disiplin , my point is you do not need to choose all the disiplines and tracks unless you want to race in all , For me Race room is not a "ooohhhhhh collect all cars and tracks" type game its a sim and carreer game a game where you follow a specific disipline and go from there be the best you can be in chosing race career , so when you get down to it , you get a game "Simulater" that you can get good at then purchase what you want to , you have choice , becuase there are plenty drivers  in each disipline , you dont have to pay for a game then pay the same price and more again for the DLC collection , you pay for what you want and its cheaper then the "Buy Game , Buy dlc , buy dlc buy dlc , and ,,,,,,,," you get the picture , buy the car you want in the disipline not need for the whole car pack and the tracks for the chosine disipline ,,,,,,,, we have a game "SIM" that you can choose what you want to do , other games ulimatley you will buy the game and all the dlc , why ? becuase all your buddy's have and you need the same to play with them , here you and your buddy's will no dought get only what you all are good at , Bottom line good game , and ultimatly one of the best sims ever even with the buy in for what you want to do , choice good stuff Simbin good stuff.Yes I know my spelling sucks, a floor of mine , i am working on it....

content:
Posted: May 26, 2013
												A great free to play simulator.  It has better graphics than Simraceway, and the sound quality is seccond to none!  This is the level of quality I have come to expect from a great publisher like SIMBIN and this is no exception.  The physics model is continually updated and they now even simulate transmission wear!  There is also a chance to try out each and every car before you buy it.  I wish the same could be said for tracks; however, once again, SIMBIN is more generous than most, if not all, in this category.  Even if you are skeptical, try it out.  If you don't like it, uninstal it.  I highly reccomend this to everyone from sim junkies to those who just want an upgrade from Need For Speed.  The highly customizable dificulty threshold means that RaceRoom is a simulator which you can grow with and (crucially, for me) does not continually hemmoarge your wallet (cough, cough, iRacing) during the process.  Unlike many games, you truly have nothing to lose beyond a few minutes of your time.  In my case, I wasn't dissapointed in the slightest.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 12, 2015
												This has got to be the most underrated racing game or simulation. It may not have the best visuals among racing games right now but it still looks really good. It's FFB even though not revolutionary is something that you can tweak to suit your preferences and it's fantastic when you do.Its problem is its annoying "race2play" (a play on "free 2 play") UI and it also only has a very few free cars and even fewer free tracks. I bought its GT Masters and DTM 2014 experiences and, man, those are fantastic. They should make separate games for those (but give it free to us who bought them here in RRE). Or at least let us configure the game to select a default "experience" during startup.AI in this game seems good. They don't display the "blind AI" or "AI without the I for intelligence" of other racing games and simulations.Currently this game is still missing some polish on the HUD elements. Like the sector split times really huge and distracting when we only need to know if we're going faster or slower for the current lap. The position bar's fonts look horrible. Those things are really well done on their older games (Race series) so I hope they could really improve this area of the game. Currently those look ugly in comparison to the rest of the game that I turn them off at the expense of feedback since the game does not have a race engineer to tell you what's going on.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 16, 2013
												This game looks awesome and its free. Free is never truly free, but that is the marketing model.This game will continue to develope for years to come. This game has come a long way since 2009. Thats right, 2009. its been reworked alot of times, and its always getting better. This is one of the most fair free to play models in the market. Each track takes hundreds of hours of work. Some of the newer tracks have the cost of laser scanning on top of the time to write it. Nearly every game out today sells dlc. This base game is free. You $40 to $60 ahead just for trying it. If you like it, then get what you like. If not, at least you did not blow $40 to $60 for a game you only play once in a while.The cars that come with the game are good enough to get a feel for the game, but if you like the game your gonna need to buy the tracks and cars you want. There are packs available to save you some money. You will probably spend $60 to $80 for the content you want if you like the game. All the content is about $250 or so.I used this on my Fanatec Wheel, and my x360 controller, both play well.At this current time most of what this game has to offer surpasses every other sim I have played including A/C. When A/C first came out, it had this beat. Now with a few updates later, it is better both graphically and in terms of physics.I only wish the game had Daytona Road Course.I have been a supporter of this game long before it was ported to steam. About 2009 or so. This game really does continue to get developed.

content:
Posted: March 5, 2016
												RaceRoom is a very good game. I've really enjoyed the hours I have spent on it so far.This is the short version of the review:Pros +The sounds are superb+The graphics are nice+The car handling is very good +The tracklist is seems very cool+The carlist is very good (Only racecars, mind you)+The menus are easy to use+The in-game interface is easy to understand+Extremely detailed tuning+The AI is goodCons-Very limited in cars and tracks if you do not pay for them-You need a gamepad or steering wheel to enjoy the game-Tyres seem to last unrealisticly long (Might just be me, I am not experienced in real racing)-Damage can only be enabled on the hardest difficulty (For explanation, see below)-The pit menu is a bit fiddlyThis is the longer version of the review:RaceRoom is a very good simulator racing game. This is how it works:There are three difficulty settings. Novice, Amateur and GetReal.Novice is the easiest. It has Traction Control, Anti-Lock Brakes and Auto Braking.Amateur is the middle ground. It only has TC and ABS.GetReal surely does what is says. It gets real. No assists enabled.GetReal is only usable for those with a gamepad or a steering wheel. On a keyboard is utterly useless.There is a damage model, but it can only be used in the "GetReal" mode, which seems odd to me. In the "GetReal" mode, you can choose if you want mechanical damage, only cosmetic or none at all. The game also includes a penalty system for corner cutting. You can set it to different kinds of penalties. A slow down penalty, a drive-through penalty or a stop-and-go penalty (Be aware, you'll have to select to serve it manually. Just driving through the pits to serve a drive-through won't work).When you don't pay any money you get acces to three tracks and seven or eight (could be wrong, might be less) cars. Two circuits and one hillclimb course. You can test drive any car you like as many times as you like, but only on a specific track. For the test drive, you can select the difficulty mode. You cannot test drive the tracks, which I think is odd.The game sounds fantastic and looks very good as well. The tuning in the game is unbelievably detailed and quite frankly scarily detailed. I daren't touch it. Overall, I think it is a great simulator which everyone interested in racing should give a try.  (This line of text contains some extra love for the people who read the review this far. I've put more time than I should have into this review)

content:
Posted: December 24, 2015
												There are some truly god aful reviews here. Not liking the game because you have to buy content is not a legitimate reason to leave a negative review.    You have to buy everything these days and why is that different here?   It's cost is comparative to any other title  when yuo add a few content packs into play.  Yes if you add them all you will spend more money then an entire game, you also end up with Laser Scanned tracks, some of the best driving physics a simulation has Graphically the game is a little behind but it IMO actually does a great job at looking the most realistic and providing most realistic feel when racing.    RF2 does an ok job here but being DX9 only is a hold back.  AC is gorgeous but not real,  Project Cars looks like a video game.  PC looks the best, but also has the worst driving model and is not realistic in look at all.  If you enjoyed Race 07, GTR2, and GTR Evolution you will like RRE.  To me this is the spiritual success of these  titles and I will continue to support both Simbing/Sector3 and ISI and their Gmotor efforts.   Ian and Project Cars well lets just say I have PCars but ill never buy it.

content:
Posted: November 8, 2015
 The Overview This game is a very well developed racing simulator similar to that of Grand Turismo on the PlayStation. It offers a very wide selection of cars/tracks to choose from, all of which have very different attributes. The game itself is very well engineered with great graphics and it actually shocked me when I saw that this game was free (you pay for extra tracks, etc.).  Pros 1. Great Graphics2. Great Sound3. No Loud Main Menu Music4. Great Map Selection5. Very Specific Settings6. Car Tuning7. Turning/Acceleration Sensativity Settings8. Free9. Many Different Modes Of Gameplay Cons 1. Turning Too Sensative (No Matter The Setting)2. Takes Alot Of Practice3. Only Get A Few Maps Free4. Turns Take Too Much Breaking (Ridiculous Amount) Conclusion I recommend this game for anyone looking for an amazing racing simulator game! This is on par with Grand Turismo and better yet, its free versus the $59.99 for the new Grand Turismo's. This game is very well developed and I look for updates to come out to fix any cons that I mentioned (most of which were just my opinion, not real problems).

content:
Posted: April 3, 2016
												Note that this really is not a free to play simulation. The free content is no good. To see what this is all about you have to spend cash to get the good packs. Basically it is like this: If you follow real life racing and have a 250 usd+ steering wheel setup and knowledge of and love for real life racing dynamics... and 100 usd+ to spend on content. Then this is your sim. It is hands down the best simulation of actual RACING ever made and with the recent updates it is very close to life like racing. Now that adaptive ai is working it is also the best simulation for single player. The fact that physics are developed in unison with the real DTM/TT drivers (whom you also see sometimes online) as well as the general engine being awesome makes this the best package right now if you have all prerequisites. If not you will not like it. You need: Expensive steering wheel set (without this, do not get it)100 USD cash for different content (without this, do not get it) Real life racing knowledge (without this, do not get it) Following of real life racing and a love for actual track racing (without this, do not get it) So, disregard the free to play thing. This is a hardcore platform for simulation racing, with a good single player structure as well. If you like some more casual "game" style get Project CarsIf you like hot-lapping with road cars get Assetto CorsaIf you like to devote 16 hours a day towards virtual league racing and disregard the rest of your life, get rFactor2 If you want a good simulation of actual racing, that is also a good single player, offline experience and need a full simulation model, get this

content:
Posted: January 19, 2014
												I love cars and 3D racing games and this game gives a good explanation of racing with a variety of tracks and cars to choose from but there are four problems. First there is only one track you have to choose from as far as I can see and you have to pay for the rest of them and I use Aussie Dollars not USD, so that makes it even harder for me to buy the game currency. Second there are only two cars you start off with, the Aquila and the BMW. There both great I can tell you that but the Aquila has just poor steering and same goes with the BMW. Third I don't know how to earn the game currrency so that is a big problem for me. Last it said 2 hours to install and it took 7 hours and I had to wait a day for it to fully load.I would recommend this game to car and racing fans but just look out for poor steering because the first track you use has a few hard turns and you have to really judge you turning because the turn, most of the time is hard to make and when your in first person view you see the steering wheel only turn a small amount not going in a full rotation like other games. You also have to wait a couple of seconds before the cars goes from N to D or N to R. Overall I did enjoy the game but its just those few problems that took some of the joy out of playing the game. I would give this game a 6.5/10.

content:
Posted: June 29, 2016
Full of exploitersUntil this has been fixed


Well done Ferran Buisan - SPA 
Community Created Artwork for RaceRoom Racing Experience 
By: Erik Taurus

			This is why I won't spend a Euro on this game until this has been fixed.		


I won't be bothered with this game because when we play online or try the leader boards the times are set by people like him.Below was my recommend review, unfortunately the leader boards still haven't been fixed and the below review was written on July 8:th 2015...Potential RaceRoom Racing Experience has as a lot of it!The game is great and simulates the cars close enough, or what I'd recon at least, there are a few things missing, but more on that later. The races can have free practise and qualifying sessions added before the race and these options are also available in multiplayer. The setup and configuration of the dedicated server is very easy. These cars, which in real races are millimetres apart and us being able to do the same whilst playing multiplayer is just awesome! Hats off for near flawless multiplayer code! The free cars you get are awesome to drive and shows that effort has been put into simulating the different behaviours of the cars. There are two racing circuits where one is a more open circuit similar to Circuit de Barcelona-Catalunya and the other a more narrow circuit similar to Circuit Gilles Villeneuve Both circuits are great fun and there are milliseconds to be gained in and out of every corner!I've yet to try the "Get real" difficulty to have a look at the different setups of the cars, but I do hope there are some pre-sets to chose from. The Jeoff Crammond Grand Prix games didn't have and see where that lead them... There are however some problems with the game. The first thing is that their marketing plan is confusing to say the least, no need for me to dig deeper into it, read the  other reviews and read the guides for the game if you are to buy content.The actual tracks could simulate more realistic features like best grip in the race line, and I'd like to see different type of weather too, like rain for example. The leader board is a joke because the fastest laps on it are now impossible to beat as changes to the tracks have made some "short cuts" invalidating the lap. A reset of the leader boards should be done ASAP! Sector3 Studios are working continuously on the game and with that in mind and seeing the potential it'll bring RaceRoom Racing Experience very far!

Posted: December 30, 2013
												This game could be THE game but it is not. For several reasons: not enough content (or so unaffordable) and no multiplayer mode. Graphically, the game is beautiful with a nice management of light and shadows, well reproduced circuits and steering feel very involved. But the game really costs too much to unlock (between 50 and 60 € at least) and thus be able to enjoy the game fully. I advise to wait an effort from SIMBIN with the lower prices of the various components of the game and the appearance of multiplayer.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 11, 2015
												Having spent some time around the various racing sims, I can say this is not the most realistic, not the best looking and not the best feeling (Force Feedback) sim out there. But currently it's my favourite,The game is free, but you have to pay for content like cars and tracks. Considering that you probably will have a few favorite rides and some favourite places to race, you don't need to buy everyting, and with that in mind the pricing is reasonable (just buy a points package and get the content you are interested in). To get everything you have to spend a significant amount of cash, but it's still cheaper than playing iRacing or something like Project CARS / Assetto Corsa with all DLC considering the amoutn of content that is available.Now for the game itself. The graphics are good, though not mind blowing, but considering that you will be focused on turning that wheel and operating the pedals, you will forget about visuals fast. The sound on the other hand is the best in the market hands down. Handling is fairly realistic, though not hardcore difficult like rFactor 2, with good Force Feedback once configured properly. Though it is possible to enhoy the game with a controller, a wheel is highly recommended.Now for the sweet parts - contrary to other sims, there is a good combination of cars and tracks. You will not see stuff like 1 car per class or useless roadcars that go slow and spin out all the time - no Ferraris and SLS AMGs, no drifting. This is all about racing. And racing is good. The AI is one of the better ones, so you will not get divebombed by crazy maniacs all the time, and the difficulty setting will accomodate players of all skill levels. Not the best AI in the market, but quite good and most of all fun,The bad stuff? No night racing or rain. Not really a big deal, since in other sims these types of races a cool to look at, but mostly hard and frustrating. Perhaps the biggest issue to me is the lack of a dynamic racing line, where the track rubbers up in places where cars drive and you have more grip there. Not really a problem, but once you try something like this in rFactor 2, you do notice it other games. Raceroom also lacks open-wheelers and does not have many classic cars, but that is to change soon. Another thing is a full flag rules system is still to be addes at some point.All in all, of all the new generation of racing sims, Raceroon seems most fun thanks to a good selection of cars and tracks and good AI. If you are looking to get into simracing this is defo the game to try. Other sims might have better graphics or laser scanned tracks, but not the AI Racerrom has nor the amount of actual racing content we see here.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2014
												First of all, I think DTM Experience might be the best racing simulation out there.  I hope that RaceRoom emulates it more and more as I'm sure it will.  Raceroom itself is still in beta and therefore it doesn't have much other than doing practice sessions with AI.  I took advantage of a sale recently and got all RaceRoom content for about $70.  That's a few dozen cars and 15-20 tracks I think.  That's a great price especially compared to another race sim that I've spent about $1,000 on (iRacing).  RaceRoom is a lot of fun. DTM is a little lacking in content (no pit stops, no rain, no mp) but some of that should come later.  At least I know the multiplayer will.  Even though it's lacking in content it is one very, very good racing simulation.  I highly recommend it.

Posted: August 7, 2015
												RaceRoom is an excellent racing sim, one of the best actually. It has amazing graphics, physics and sounds. It runs smooth but there's one flaw and it's somewhat big. The real downside of this game is it's purchasing system and expandability. Remember, this game is free, but in reality, it's not. There is a plethora of cars and tracks, however, you only get a very small handful of each as Free to play. And I mean pretty small where I'd be dying to try the cars and tracks that you would need to buy each one separately, which to me is a gimmick.Overall, RaceRoom is a great game and all, it's just that the developers had incorporated a very ♥♥♥♥♥♥ expansion system. In my sense, I would've rather paid for the game to get all of the features in place of it being free.

												Simple as this:I do not like the format much, Pay to Play twists me the wrong way and I would not like to see it re appearing too much andtherefore I do not have a lot of experience with this sim as I would rather pay for something up front, however, I can still say that this is a fantastic sim by Sector 3 Studios and well worth a look, but, for now, whilst I am in the financial deficit I am in, I shall stick to the cheap-and-cheerful Race 07, which is cheaper, just less advanced by this in terms of the same engine (in terms of physics, graphics and sound) and the... not so intelligent Artificial Intelligence, which are MUCH better in RaceRoom. Overall, If you are willing to spend a lot, get this game, If not, get another - older - game, which would be cheaper.

content:
Posted: December 18, 2014
												This game has come a long way from the very first time I tried it back in early 2013 and is very solid for a Beta release, it has a lot of potential for a f2p game. The sound is amazing and the physics need just a little improvement. The tracks look amazing and the tracks made by the developer are fun and challenging. My only major critisism is the AI which is a long way in my opinion from being complete, they will ram you time and again if you're on a turn and they accelerate faster than you. The control system could use a little work and be more descriptive on how the sensitivity settings for controller (using a wired Xbox 360 controller until I can afford a descent steeling wheel rig) because after many sessions of tweaking the settings for steering acceleration I am still lost on how the settings affect my controller. Other than that this game is definitely worth a try if you are looking into Racing Sims. 9/10

content:
Posted: October 7, 2015
												I actually don’t recommend RaceRoom Racing Experience BUT...I took a moment to look through some of the positive and negative reviews prior to writing this and realized some things which actually changed my opinion of the game from the perspective of functional game content.The one criticism I have which has not changed is the sound. I’m not a professional racer, I don’t know what it sounds like to be behind the wheel of one of these monstrosities, but when I play a racing game with a 5.1 surround system I expect it to feel raw and powerful. Instead, I found all of the vehicles to sound unbelievably anemic and whiny. Again, I have no idea what these cars may sound like in real life, but this is a game. It’s disappointing to see such aggressive speed machines yet hear whiny little RC cars.Now one of the first things I learn was that this is (at least in some capacity) the same people responsible for Race07. I recently gave that game a whirl and had a nauseatingly terrible experience with it. Whatever they learned from those past titles they have clearly refined it and mastered it for RaceRoom. I know a lot of time has passed between the two, but it’s hard to think this quality sim is from the same people behind Race07. Great job, devs; keep up the iteration and self improvement!The next thing I took a step back from complaining about was the Free-to-Play model. Many of the negative reviews pointed out the frankly incomprehensible way in which content is being sold. I think the model is confusing and poorly thought out, but I don’t think the fact that you are expected to pay for the majority of the cars when the game and a handful of vehicles are completely free is a point to merit a negative review. The game is extremely detailed and - as best I can tell - extremely faithful to the physics behind circuit racing. RaceRoom isn’t a Free-to-Play racing game in my eyes; it’s a demo for a well crafted racing simulator that allows you to pay for exactly the content you want if you decide that the mechanics interest you.I didn’t much enjoy it, but RaceRoom Racing Experience is a free demo for a very high quality racing simulator. If you’re into this genre and like what you see in the screenshots, you should absolutely try out the game. There is literally nothing to lose by trying it out.

content:
Posted: August 25, 2016
												♥♥♥♥♥game. Cars feel like driving through a foot of water because when you turn they don't respond nearly like they should. I have a DFGT and have played other racing sims, such as iRacing, Project CARS, Assetto Corsa, etc. I don't claim to be the best at them, I suck pretty bad actually. But this game just flat out doesn't feel right at all. The steering response is simply horrible.On top of that, setting my DFGT up so that it would actually work properly and give me 900 degrees of steering in this game was a royal pain in the♥♥♥♥♥ I've had no problems in any other game with this wheel, but in this game it literally took me 30 minutes just to figure out how to get 900 degrees of steering, and the solution was to disable the hand animations, which speaks to the poor quality of this game. Don't waste your money, if you're going to buy anything in this game, get iRacing and buy things in that instead, it's a much better investment.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 20, 2016
												Okay, you guys who read me might say: "This guys doesn't know the f*ck he's talking about, he only has 4.4 hrs on record!"...but hear me out real quick; I've played simulation games since my young age back in the days with Gran Turismo 1 on the 1st PS system, and I can tell you that on the "sim" side of things, this game nails it badly. 1) The sounds are majestic: all the cars that I've bought for DLC and that I've heard in real life sound exactly the same...I've been waiting for a long time for this to happen in a video game (Zonda R = music to my ears, you must try that car out).2) The graphics aren't "Project Cars"-like, but they certainly do please my eyes...3) Its free....so you have nothing to loose...try it out with the few cars/tracks that they offer and see for yourself if you want to get into the game deeper with the tons of add-ons that they offer at a fair price for their content :)4) It doesn't take a deadly gaming setup to run it on a decent quality and decent FPS rate (im running a GTX 750Ti, probably the most mid-range GPU u could have, with a 4th gen i5 and 8 GB of RAM, and I run the game maxed out at around 100 FPS, sometimes going down to 40-50FPS when big crashes happen).On the negative side of things, I would recommend that, if you really like this game, you should invest in a good quality wheel (a simple low-range logitec runs like a dream on mine), but most racing simulator fans already have one just like me...All that said, I hope this was helpfull to you, and note that this game is used by some professional drivers to test their skills on some tracks, just to prove that the simulation is mostly flawless...

content:
Posted: November 29, 2016
												- Terrible microtransaction business model.- Horrible development, the game ran better over a year ago and has suffered from constant connection issues, lag and stuttering since then, and when an update finally arrives, it makes it worse and they can't seem to fix the main issues as they claim the "need" to be online because of how the store and steam wallet are set up. (no online server connection = can't play)- Claims to be a "simulator", but without the essential features. (tire pressure, etc.) In fact, RaceRoom uses the same physics engine as AMS and Project Cars but feels like your driving on a skateboard and once you compare Pcars to RaceRoom you will see the simularities and realize that Project Cars feels more realistic and also comes with better graphics, VR support, tracks, and cars along with dynamic weather/night for a fraction of the cost ($29.99) compared to the content prices in RaceRoom...Just sayin.Be cautious. Don't make the same mistake I did, If your looking for an actual "simulator" experience, then rFactor 2 and Assetto Corsa are the way to go with MUCH better value, physics, features, content and moddibility. Even Pcars blows this game away. These guys (Sector 3) aren't interested in giving the community what they want for a better experience, they are just out for your $$$ by peddling content and a half baked VR via a microtransaction model.This game is dying. My advice if your looking for games in this genre is to pick up AC, PCars, and rF2 for a fraction of the cost of owning only 1/2 of RaceRoom content (unless you have the money to burn and hard drive space to spare)
